entries.fullText:
FIRST CLASS. - Letters and all written matter, whether sealed or unsealed, and all other matter sealed, nailed, sewed, tied, or fastened in any manner, so that it cannot be easily examined, two cents per ounce or fraction thereof. A "Special Delivery" ten-cent stamp, when attached to a letter in addition to the lawful postage, shall entitle the letter to immediate delivery at, or within one mile of, any post-office. Postal cards, one cent each; with paid reply, two cents each.

SECOND CLASS. - All regular newspapers, magazines and other periodicals issued at intervals not exceeding three months; the postage is one cent for each four ounces, payable by postage stamps.

THIRD CLASS. - Embraces printed books, pamphlets, circulars, engravings, lithographs, proof-sheets and manuscript accompanying the same, and all matter of the same general character, and not having the character of personal correspondence. Circulars produced by hektograph or similar process, or by electric pen, are rated as third class. The limit of weight for mail matter of the third class is four pounds, except in the case of single books exceeding that weight. The rate of postage on mail matter of the third class is one cent for each two ounces or fraction thereof.

FOURTH CLASS.- All mailable matter not included in the three preceding classes, which is so prepared for mailing as to be easily taken from the wrapper and examined. Rate, one cent per ounce or fraction thereof, except seeds, roots, cuttings, bulbs, plants and scions, which are 1 cent per two ounces. Limit of weight, 4 lbs. Full prepayment compulsory. Liquids, and other like injurious matter, not admitted, except under conditions which may be learned at any post-office.
Register all valuable letters and packages. Registry fee, eight cents, which, with the postage, must be fully prepaid.

FEES CHARGED FOR MONEY-ORDERS.- For Money Orders in denominations of $100 or less, the following fees are charged: For Orders for sums not exceeding $2.50, 3 cents; $2.50 to $5, 5 cents; $5 to $10, 8 cents; $10 to $20, 10 cents; $20 to $30, 12 cents; $30 to $40, 15 cents; $40 to $50, 18 cents; $50 to $60, 20 cents; $60 to $75, 25 cents; $75 to $100, 30 cents.
entries.summaryText: This entry explains the different classes of mail and their corresponding rates, as well as the fees charged for money orders.

entries.fullText:
To all Foreign Countries (except Canada and Mexico):
On Letters, five cents for each half ounce or fraction thereof - prepayment optional. Double rates are collected on delivery of unpaid or short-paid letters.
On newspapers, books, pamphlets, photographs, sheet music, maps, engravings, and similar printed matter, one cent for each two ounces or fraction thereof.

TO CANADA (including Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Manitoba, and Prince Edward Island): LETTERS, two cents for each ounce or fraction thereof: Books, Circulars, and similar printed matter, one cent for each two ounces or fraction thereof; SECOND CLASS MATTER, same as in the United States; Samples, 1 cent per 2 ounces (must be paid at least 2 cents); MERCHANDISE, one cent per ounce. Packages must not exceed 4 lbs. 6 ozs. in weight - prepayment compulsory. No sealed packages other than letters in their usual and ordinary form may be sent by mail to Canada.

TO MEXICO: Letters, Postal Cards, and printed matter, same rates as in the United States. SAMPLES, one cent per two ounces; MERCHANDISE other than Samples can only be sent by Parcel Post. No sealed packages other than letters in their usual and ordinary form may be sent by mail to Mexico.

LIMITS OF SIZE AND WEIGHT: Packages of samples of merchandise to the countries named above (except Great Britain, France, Belgium, and Switzerland) must not exceed 8 3/4 ozs., nor measure more than 12 in. in length, 8 in breadth, and 4 in depth; and packages of printed matter must not exceed 4 lbs. 6 ozs. Packages of merchandise samples to Great Britain, France, Belgium, Switzerland, Italy, Austria, Hawaii, and Argentine Republic are limited to 12 ozs. in weight, 12 in. in length, 8 in width, and 4 in depth. Packages of printed matter to Germany and Great Britain are limited to 2 ft. in length and 1 ft. in each other dimension.

INTERNATIONAL OR FOREIGN MONEY-ORDER FEES.
On Money Orders payable in foreign countries the following fees are charged: For Orders for sums of $10 or less, 10c.; over $10 and not exceeding $20, 20c.; over $20 and not exceeding $30, 30c.; over $30 and not exceeding $40, 40c.; over $40 and not exceeding $50, 50c.; over $50 and not exceeding $60, 60c.; over $60 and not exceeding $70, 70c.; over $70 and not exceeding $80, 80c.; over $80 and not exceeding $90, 90c.; over $90 and not exceeding $100, $1.00.
entries.summaryText: This entry explains the rates and limits for mailing to foreign countries, including Canada and Mexico, as well as the fees charged for international money orders.

entries.fullText:
DROWNING.-- 1. Loosen clothing, if any. 2. Empty
lungs of water by laying body on its stomach, and lifting it
by the middle so that the head hangs down. Jerk the body
a few times. 3. Pull tongue forward, using handkerchief, or
pin with string, if necessary. 4. Imitate motion of respiration
by alternately compressing and expanding the lower
ribs, about twenty times a minute. Alternately raising and
lowering the arms from the sides up above the head will
stimulate the action of the lungs. Let it be done gently
but persistently. 5. Apply warmth and friction to extremities.
6. By holding tongue forward, closing the nostrils,
and pressing the "Adam's apple" back (so as to close
entrance to stomach), direct inflation may be tried. Take a
deep breath and breathe it forcibly into the mouth of patient,
compress the chest to expel the air, and repeat the
operation. 7. DON'T GIVE UP! People have been saved
after HOURS of patient, vigorous effort. 8. When breathing
begins, get patient into a warm bed, give WARM drinks, or
spirits in teaspoonfuls, fresh air, and quiet.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone who is drowning.

entries.fullText:
SUNSTROKE.-- There are two important indications for
treatment - reduction of temperature and the use of stimulants.
The patient should first be removed to a cooler spot
if possible, or at least where shade can be secured. The
treatment should be begun at once. The clothing about the
neck and body must be either loosened or removed. Cold
is particularly indicated in cases where there is great heat
of the body, and delirium and convulsive movements are
present. This means of reducing the temperature may be
applied in the shape of cracked ice about the head and spine,
or the use of cold water. If the heat of the body is very
great, it may be necessary to wrap the patient in sheets wet
with cold water. If there is, besides the great heat, evidence
of serious depression, stimulants must be used while the cold
is being applied.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone with sunstroke.

entries.fullText:
HEMORRHAGE.-- The usual treatment is rest in the recumbent
position; small pieces of ice should be freely swallowed,
and the application of ice wrapped in a towel or in an
ice-bag, or snow, cold water, etc., over the stomach; hot
applications may be applied to the extremities.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone with hemorrhage.

entries.fullText:
FIRE IN A BUILDING.-- Crawl on the floor. The clearest
air is the lowest in the room. Cover head with woolen wrap,
wet if possible. Cut holes for the eyes. Don't get excited.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a fire in a building.

entries.fullText:
BURNS AND SCALDS.-- Cover with cooking soda and lay
wet clothes over it. Whites of eggs and olive oil. Olive oil or
linseed oil, plain, or mixed with chalk or whiting. Sweet or
olive oil and lime-water. Shock, which is always present in
severe burns, requires the administration of stimulants. Pain
is more constant and intense in burns than in any other form
of injury, and requires sedatives, which should be administered
by the medical attendant. Later on the appearances
of inflammation and other complications are to be carefully
watched for.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone with burns and scalds.

entries.fullText:
SUFFOCATION FROM INHALING ILLUMINATING GAS.
-- Get into the fresh air as soon as possible and lie down.
Keep warm. Take ammonia -- twenty drops to a tumbler
of water, at frequent intervals; also, two to four drops
tincture of nux vomica every hour or two for five or six
hours.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone who has inhaled illuminating gas.

entries.fullText:
TESTS OF DEATH.-- Hold mirror to mouth. If living,
moisture with gather. Push pin into flesh. If dead, the hole
will remain; if alive, it will close up. Place fingers in front
of a strong light. If alive, they will appear red; if dead,
black or dark.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to test if someone is dead.

entries.fullText:
MAD DOG OR SNAKE-BITE.--Tie cord tight above
wound. Suck the wound and cauterize with caustic or
white-hot iron at once, or cut out the adjoining parts with a
sharp knife. Give stimulants, as whisky, brandy, etc.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone who has been bitten by a mad dog or snake.

entries.fullText:
FIRE IN ONE'S CLOTHING.-- Don't run -- especially not
downstairs or out-of-doors. Roll on carpet, or wrap in
woolen rug or blanket. Keep the head down, so as not to
inhale flame.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a fire in one's clothing.

entries.fullText:
FIRE FROM KEROSENE.-- Don't use water, it will spread
the flames. Dirt, sand, or flour is the best extinguisher, or
smother with woolen rug, table-cloth, or carpet.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of a fire from kerosene.

entries.fullText:
CINDERS IN THE EYE.-- Roll soft paper up like a lamp
lighter, and wet the tip to remove, or use a medicine dropper
to draw it out. Rub the other eye.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to remove cinders from the eye.

entries.fullText:
FAINTING.-- Place flat on back; allow fresh air, and
sprinkle with water. Place head lower than rest of body.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case of fainting.

entries.fullText:
STINGS OF VENOMOUS INSECTS, ETC.-- Apply weak
ammonia, oil, salt water, or iodine.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to help someone who has been stung by venomous insects.

entries.fullText: LIGHTNING.-- Dash cold water over a person struck.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on what to do in case someone is struck by lightning.

entries.fullText:
FIRST. - Send for a physician.
SECOND. - INDUCE VOMITING, by tickling throat with
feather or finger. Drink hot water or strong mustard and
water. Swallow sweet oil or whites of eggs.
Acids are antidotes for alkalies, and vice versa.

ACIDS, MINERAL. - Chalk, magnesia (plaster off wall in
emergency), solution carbonate of soda, emollient drinks,
fixed oils.
ACID, CARBOLIC. - Any soluble sulphate, such as magnesia.
ACID, HYDROCYANIC. - Fresh air and artificial respiration,
with cold effusion. Ammonia by inhalation and intraveneously
in vein of leg.
ACONITE. - Emetics, stimulants, external an internal;
keep up external heat, keep flat on back.
ANTIMONY TART. - Vegetable acids, such as tannic acid, catechu.
ARSENIC. - Freshly precipitated hydrated sesquioxide of iron made by adding magnesia to any iron solution.
ATROPIA. - Same as Belladonna.
BELLADONNA. - Emetics - mustard flour in water; give physostigma or pilocarpine; cold to head.
CANTHARIDES. - Emetics, emollient drinks, opiates by mouth and rectum, large draughts of water to flush kidneys.
CHLORINE WATER. - Albumen, white of egg, milk, flour.
CHLOROFORM. - Fresh air, artificial respiration (inclining head down, pull tongue forward), brandy and ammonia intravenously in leg, the HYPODERMIC injection of 15 m. tincture of digitalis and I-60 of a grain of atropine.
COLCHICUM. - Emetics, followed by demulcent drinks. If coma be present brandy, ammonia, coffee. Opium in large dose. Keep up external heat.
CONIUM. - Emetics, followed by stimulants external and internal.
CORROSIVE SUBLIMATE. - Albumen, white of egg (4 gr. sublimate require white of one egg), flour, milk. Equal parts of lime water and milk. Emetics, or evacuate stomach by pump.
entries.summaryText: Instructions on how to deal with poisoning and the corresponding antidotes.

entries.fullText:
Poisons and Antidotes

COPPER SULPH. - Yellow prussiate of potash or soap.
CROTON OIL. - Emetics; wash out stomach, followed by mucilaginous fluids, containing opium.
DIGITALIS. - Recumbent posture after emetics. Emetics and opium; give tincture aconite.
ELATERIUM. - Demulcent drinks, enemeta of opium, and external heat.
HYOSCYAMUS. - Stomach pump, emetics, stimulants external and internal, physostigma and pilocarpine.
ILLUMINATING GAS. - Hypodermic injections of nitroglycerin are recommended by Kloman, of Baltimore.
IODINE. - Emetics and demulcent drinks, starch or flour diffused in water, opium and external heat.
LEAD SALTS. - Any soluble sulphate, either magnesia or soda, succeeded by emetics, and afterwards by opium and milk.
LOBELLA. - Stimulants externally and internally; external heat.
MORPHINE. - Same as opium.
NUX VOMICA. - 30 grs. of chloral and 60 grs. of bromide of potash. Nitrite of amyl.
OPIUM. - Atropine hypodermically till respirations number 8 per minute. Stomach pump, stimulants, external and internal, brandy and coffee, cold affusion, ammonia to nostrils, galvanic shocks, compelling to move about, artificial respiration, electric brush. Permanganate of Potash.
OXALIC ACID. - Lime, not potash or soda.
PHOSPHORUS. - Sulphate of copper in emetic dose as chemical antidote. No oils. Emetics and purgatives.
POTASH AND SODA SALTS. - Dilute acetic acid, citric acid, lemon juice, fixed oils, demulcents, vinegar.
SILVER NITRATE. - Solution of common salt and demulcent drinks. Emetics.
STRAMONIUM. - Same as Belladonna.
STRYCHNINE. - Same as Nux Vomica.
TOBACCO. - Emetic, stimulants, external and internal, strychnine, external heat.
ZINC SALTS. - Carbonate of soda, emetics, warm demulcent drinks.
entries.summaryText: A list of poisons and their corresponding antidotes.

entries.fullText:
Arrived in New York at
10 a.m. Train three hours
late -- went cousin
I. H. Laphams [?] -- found
Mr. G. M. Catt waiting
for me there -- met warm
welcome -- took cup of
coffee & light breakfast --
after went with Mr. Catt to
Stern home -- Bensonhurst --
taking fully two hours
Found Mrs. Blackwell & Mrs.
Upton there -- soon Miss Shaw
came without Rachel -- So
we now had Anthony show
Blackwell, Upton, Catt -- a [quinine]
of our B.C. -- Mrs. C had a very
nice dinner with regulation
four courses -- just after dark
Rachel came -- making
all of the com. [?] the two
auditors -- Clay & M. Cullock
all together talked over
all branches of the work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in New York and met with several people, including Mr. G. M. Catt, Mrs. Blackwell, Mrs. Upton, Miss Shaw, Rachel, Clay, and M. Cullock, to discuss the work.

entries.fullText:
At Bensonhurst --
Business Com. began work
in real earnest this a.m.
& kept it going until dinner,
then until supper, then until
10 p.m. -- Rachel & Harriet
as usual slept or lay awake
together -- hence were sleepy all
the day -- Mr. Catt went
to Office in New York -- &
returned full of aches -- which
grew worse until at 7:20
Mrs. Catt walked a mile
to call his doctor -- who came
gave him big dose of quinine
then [Blue Mass] -- then a
Setlitz Powder -- all of which
he vomited up strait way --
so that Mrs. Catt just out of
a severe grippe siege was up
with Mr. C. all the night --
entries.summaryText: Business Com. began work in real earnest. Mr. Catt went to Office in New York and returned full of aches. Mrs. Catt walked a mile to call his doctor.

entries.fullText:
At Bensonhurst
Mr. C. worse -- & kept in bed
all the day -- Mrs. Upton
began feeling grippey -- so
we had a lame feeling
in our Com. meeting --
At noon Mrs. Marianne
W. Chapman of Brooklyn
came & finished with us --
& invited all to Luncheon
with her tomorrow -- but
it proved that not one -- save
Alice Blackwell could accept
-- Rachel & Shaw were to leave
in morning-- Mrs. Upton's grippe had de-
veloped so that she would stay
over with Mrs. Catt -- In p.m.
Mrs. Ida H. Harper came -- so we
had her to talk Press work -- &
there was much talking had
very little actually decided
entries.summaryText: Mr. C. worse and kept in bed all day. Mrs. Upton began feeling grippey. Mrs. Marianne W. Chapman of Brooklyn came and invited all to Luncheon with her tomorrow.

entries.fullText:
Left Bensonhurst - 2 P.M
Shaw - Foster Avery & Blackwell
left in forenoon -- Mrs Harper
& self after Lunch -- we
called at Sun Office -- Mr
Paul Dana came out to
see us -- and seemed ready
& willing to grant us space
in the Sunday Sun -- for
expression of sentiments from
stand point of woman -- and
had Mrs Harper prepare
an article such as we desire
for the Sun of Sunday Jan 15th
so we felt we had gained a
splendid page for our cause.
Then we called on Mrs
Westover Alden -- of the Tribune
-- there found that my old
clerk on Revolution in 1869 -- who
had been on Tribune ever since
had married several years ago
a foreigner some 28 years her junior
oh! oh!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Harper left Bensonhurst and visited the Sun Office where they met with Mr. Paul Dana who agreed to grant them space in the Sunday Sun. They also visited Mrs. Westover Alden of the Tribune and found out that her old clerk had married a foreigner 28 years her junior.

entries.fullText:
In New York -- at Cousin S.V.L.
Mrs Harper came to my cousin
S.V. Laphams with me last
night--& met a cordial welcome--
- This A.M. Cousin sent us
in carriage to Mrs E. Cady
Stanton's - 250 West 94th St -
- Mrs H. remained to lunch --
had a nice talk with Mrs. S.
& her charming younger daughter
Harriot Stanton Blatch -- & left
about 4 P.M. for Washington --
Cousin Carrie Vail Ladd
came for me about 6 -- and
I went back to cousin's
No 10 East 68th Street --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Harper visited Cousin S.V.L. in New York and were sent in a carriage to visit Mrs. E. Cady Stanton at 250 West 94th St. They had a nice talk with Mrs. S. and her daughter Harriot Stanton Blatch before leaving for Washington. Susan B. Anthony then returned to Cousin S.V.L.'s house at No 10 East 68th Street.

entries.fullText: In New York -- Cousin Samantha sent me over to [the Stantons again] 439 -- East 88th Street where I spent the day -- with Mrs Martha Brown Mosher -- nephew Arthur A, Mosher's wife -- no this day was with Mrs Stanton --
entries.summaryText: Spent the day in New York with Cousin Samantha and Mrs Martha Brown Mosher and nephew Arthur A, Mosher's wife and Mrs Stanton.

entries.fullText: In New York -- and this [??] with Mattie & niece Guelma -- & Arthur Jr's wife - at nephew A. A. Moshers -- Guelma left about 4 P.M. to go to Orange -- Geo. A. Vails -- she sings in Cong. church there -- -- Nephew Harry A. Baker did not get home to dinner -- Miss Powell -- cousin L's companion & house-keeper came for me -- at 8 Oclock
entries.summaryText: Spent the day in New York with Mattie, niece Guelma, and Arthur Jr's wife at nephew A. A. Moshers. Guelma left to go to Orange to sing in Cong. church there. Miss Powell came for me at 8 O'clock.

entries.fullText:
In New York
at Cousin S. V. Lapham
went to Episcopal Church
Cor. 66th st & Madison Ave
to see & hear Rev Heber
Newton - with cousin
Carrie Ladd - sat in pew
with Cousin Louis Lapham's
wife & little Eleanor - after
the ceremonials were
all through - & the
Rev. Newton took his
place to give his sermon,
it was delightfully progressive
- on the 'Flowerings
of Christianity' - but it
seemed so incongruous
with all the 'Tom Foolery' of
the performances before it -
Nephew Harry Baker
called this eve'g - told
of his wonderful power
now gained- to last!!
entries.summaryText: Attended an Episcopal Church in New York with family and heard a progressive sermon by Rev Heber Newton. Nephew Harry Baker visited and shared about his newfound power.

entries.fullText:
In New York--
at Cousin Semantha's -
After dinner - the
carriage came round &
Cousin Carrie Ladd & I
first called at 211 East I0th St
Cousin Emily Clark Griggs --
but found her gone to
Poland Her. Co. for a
change -- there she supports
her only brother Lemuel -- who,
has never been self-supporting --
Then I just called at
Mrs Stantons -- where I found
Antoinette Brown Blackwell waiting
to see me & tell me her grievance
over my book & the incident at
Gerritt Smiths in 1859 -- felt it
gave wrong impression -- but
I could not see how it was so --
Then Carrie drove me
out to Riverside -- & Grant's
Monument -- it is very
imposing -- then back to No. 10.
where we played Desperation
all the evening -- I really got
so I could see the game --
entries.summaryText: Visited family and friends in New York, including Cousin Emily Clark Griggs and Antoinette Brown Blackwell. Went to Riverside and played Desperation in the evening.

entries.fullText: Mrs Lapham sent me over to Mrs Stantons - and we talked & she wrote or began to - a form of petition to Congress - but chatting consumed most of the day - so that Mrs Stanton begged me to come over one day more - But while her mind is bright as ever - she is so handi-capped & she cannot dictate to a Stenographer - a bit better than she used to speak extempore -- she can write - but cant read it after written - nor can she hold the sentences in mind to make them right -- she always must see her words to improve her sentences - It is too bad!!
entries.summaryText: Mrs Lapham sent Susan B. Anthony to Mrs. Stanton's house in New York to work on a petition to Congress. Mrs. Stanton is struggling with her eyesight and cannot dictate to a stenographer.

entries.fullText: From Mrs Stanton's earnest appeal I gave her this one more day and at night - When Hattie read over the petition & appeal her mother had sent to be mailed to Mr Dana - she said - & is this all that Mother has done after urging you to stay over? - Well it is very sad to see her so nearly blind - that she cannot even read over what she writes -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed an extra day at Mrs. Stanton's house in New York to help with a petition to Congress. Mrs. Stanton's daughter was disappointed with the progress made due to her mother's failing eyesight.

entries.fullText:
[and yet another
day] -- and Wednesday -
P.M. -- she mailed
to Mr. Paul Dana
the joint product
of petitions to Congress & appeal
to women to circulate it
This A.M. at 11. I took
day train for home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony mails joint product of petitions to Congress and appeal to women to circulate it to Mr. Paul Dana in New York and takes the day train for home.

entries.fullText:
Left New York
on 11. A.M. train &
reached home at
9. -- [?] -- was
met at door by a
nurse -- & learned
that both my sister
Mary & little girl Annie
had been under her
care a week -- with
La Grippe -- both seem
better -- however --
No this was Thursday-- so yesterday
-- All of this day -- Friday --
I was at home -- looking
over the letters that had come
during my twelve days absence
& the nurse -- did the
house-work - with some help
from all of us --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returns home from New York and learns that her sister Mary and little girl Annie have been under the care of a nurse for a week with La Grippe. She spends the day at home looking over letters and the nurse does the housework with some help from all of them.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at home
Sister Mary & Annie
both up this A.M. -
& sister Mary discharged
the nurse -
- all wrong - but
that is her way - and
it costs me too
much feeling to insist
against it - so
we are left with
two convalescents
& one good-for-nothing --
to look on - !!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her sister Mary and Annie being up and Mary discharging the nurse, leaving them with two convalescents and one person who is not doing well.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at home
Went to church --
Had calls in P.M.
so did not get down
town for the N. Y. Sun
until 8 P.M. -- there
bought 5 copies at The
Powers Hotel -- & found
Mrs Harper's article -- but Mrs
Stanton's & my petition & appeal
before it -- with the heading
"The Cause of Woman" -- Very
good -- but too weak!!
Sent copies at once to
Woman's Journal & Tribune
Mrs Harpers good
but lacked well sharpened
points to the items -- so
it seemed -- still I scribbled
& took to letter box -- "well done
Jimmy Grine" -- It will be
splendid if the Sun
will let her give our
patriotic woman's thought
of things every Sunday!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about going to church, having calls in the afternoon, and buying copies of the N. Y. Sun at the Powers Hotel. She found Mrs. Harper's article but thought it lacked well-sharpened points. She sent copies to the Woman's Journal & Tribune and hopes the Sun will let her give their patriotic woman's thought of things every Sunday.

entries.fullText:
A young girl stenographer
came this A.M. from
Gertrude Blackwells recommendation
- though she wasn't [?] -
- Cochrane is the name -
- but at once she
showed too little
education - this
is the weak point
with nearly every girl
who comes
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a young girl stenographer who came recommended by Gertrude Blackwell but showed too little education.

entries.fullText:
Wrestling with the
piles of letters
accumulated &
my raw hand
at stenography--
- Mrs. Hawley is
improving - but doesn't
expect to be able
to work in weeks -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about wrestling with piles of letters and her raw hand at stenography. She also mentions that Mrs. Hawley is improving but doesn't expect to be able to work in weeks.

entries.fullText:
The Nominating - and
Constitution making
Committees for Local
Council called here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the Nominating and Constitution making Committees for Local Council being called to her home.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw came in
to dinner from
Ithica -- where she
had spoken the
night-before -- so
we had a good
chat over things
and in evening went to the
P.E. Church Sociable -- at Mrs
Coleman's 27 Madison st --
where Miss Marion Wright gave
a stereoptical talk on the
Nile & pyramids of Egypt -- &
after it, Miss Weaver gave
a talk -- then refreshments &
home by eleven Oclock --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about having dinner with Miss Shaw and attending a P.E. Church Sociable at Mrs. Coleman's house where Miss Marion Wright gave a talk on the Nile and pyramids of Egypt and Miss Weaver also gave a talk.

entries.fullText: At home. Miss Shaw spent the day until 4. P.M. then left for Castile -- Wyoming County -- to speak tonight - so she couldnt go to the Ethical Club meeting -- Sister Mary went -- & a motion to join the Local [Ro?] was carried unanimously
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw left for Castile to speak tonight. Sister Mary went to the Ethical Club meeting and a motion to join the Local [Ro?] was carried unanimously.

entries.fullText: At home. Miss Shaw returned at 6 P.M. It was awfully icy on the walks -- so that I turned back -- after starting to go to meet her - Sister Mary got back from Woman's Union Tea at the Watson House -- almost at same moment after Miss Shaw's arrival --
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw returned home and it was icy on the walks. Sister Mary got back from Woman's Union Tea at the Watson House almost at the same moment after Miss Shaw's arrival.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary went
to church -- but
I did not -- she bro't
package of letters --
At 4. P.M. I sent
little Annie Dann
down town for the
N. Y. Sun & Co -- there
were placed before Mrs
Harpers article -- one from
Mrs Blake -- & one from
the Anti-suffrage -- both
longer than Mrs H.s - and
her's evidently chopped out --
again -- Everything seemed
shorn of its pith & point --
Still I sent it out --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go to church and received letters. She sent someone to get the N.Y. Sun and placed letters before Mrs. Harper's article.

entries.fullText:
At home
A new stenographer
Miss Bennett -- came
looks as if she might
learn how -- but we
shall see --
Miss Shaw gave
her some dictations
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a new stenographer named Miss Bennett and Miss Shaw gave her some dictations.

entries.fullText:
At home --
Struggling with the
vast files of
letters -- trying answer
all -- Sister Mary
went with Henry Willis
to see his mother Mrs.
Mary Willis at Canadian
[?] & returned at 5 --
Miss Shaw spent day
until 5 -- then went to
[?] to lecture --
I gave a hasty, crisp
retort to sister Mary this A.M.
in presence of Miss -- to her
saying I would better go & pay
express charge on Mrs Harpers
"trunk" -- it does get very [?]
to be constantly rubbed on
not being able to do a thing
but give away all I have
but it does hurt me
beyond words to allow a sharp word
entries.summaryText: Struggling with the vast files of letters, Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with Sister Mary and Miss Shaw. Susan gives a hasty, crisp retort to Sister Mary in the presence of Miss. Miss Shaw leaves to lecture and Sister Mary goes with Henry Willis to see his mother in Canadian.

entries.fullText:
At home
Social Council formed
this P.M. at Watson House --
34 societies present -- a
good start -- with
Mrs Joseph OConnor Pres
" George Hollister Vice Pres
" Mrs J. Y. B. Severance Rec. Scy
" Louis Bigelow Cor. Scy
Mrs Charles Fitzsimons Treas
-- It was a hard job
to get women to
take the offices --
To day a letter from
Mrs Harper says she
sent the Sun exactly
2500 words -- & only
900 - were left & put in Sun--
so some one cut out
1600 - words nearly two
thirds -- I at once wrote
Dana to ask why -- & if he
cut down Blakes & the [?]!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home and forms a Social Council at Watson House with 34 societies present. Mrs. Harper sends a letter saying that only 900 out of 2500 words were published in the Sun and Susan writes to Dana to ask why and if he cut down Blakes and the [?].

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs. Oconnor & Mrs Olive Morrison
Tea from 2 to 5 -- this P.M. --
& on Friday P.M. we went
to Watson House to Co. Ed.
meeting Mrs Montgomery gave [?] -
at evening we went to the
Unitarian parish supper -- nice
gotten up by Mrs Blanchard --
Weather awfully cold

[*I reached home --
& found Sister Mary
had just gotten in --
she knew no more
of my whereabouts
than I did of hers --
but we were glad we
reached home -- but it
beat any wind storm
I ever was out in my
own city -- *]
entries.summaryText: Tea party with Mrs. Oconnor & Mrs Olive Morrison, Co. Ed. meeting at Watson House, and Unitarian parish supper.

entries.fullText:
At Home
This is our dear father's
105th birth day as last
December 2d was our dear
mother's 105th birth day --

[*This should have been on
last page -- Sister Mary & self
went to the Tea -- 2 to 6 -- at
Mrs Joseph OConnor & Miss
Olive Morrison -- the niece &
inheritor of Miss Eliz. P. Hall --
in her old home at
Frank street -- it seemed
as if all of Rochesters women
were there -- as we
started home a little after 6 --
the rain & snow began to come --
& very soon a regular tornado
of wind -- which separated us --
Sister Mary worked her way home -
at Allen St Bridge -- a whirl took
my spectacles off -- my velvet cloak over
my head -- & I stood - finally some young
man came along -- and found my glasses --
& me with his sister took me to keys
store -- & [?] with Mr V's [?] - *]
entries.summaryText: Celebrating parents' birthdays, tea party with Mrs. Joseph OConnor & Miss Olive Morrison, and a windy walk home with Sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs. Oconnor & Mrs Olivia Morrison
Tea from 2 to 5 -- this P.M. --
& on Friday P.M. we went
to Watson House to Co. Ed.
meeting Mrs Moritzons gave plans -
at evening we went to the
Unitarian Parish Supper -- nice
gotten up by Mrs Blondell
Weather awfully cold
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a tea and a Co. Ed. meeting at Watson House, as well as a Unitarian Parish Supper.

entries.fullText:
I reached home -
& found sister May
had just gotten in
she knew no more
of my whereabouts
than I did of hers -
but we were glad we
reached home - but it
beat any wind storm
I ever was out in my
own city
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about returning home during a wind storm and being reunited with her sister.

entries.fullText:
At Home
This is our dear father's
105th birth day as last
December 2d was our dear
mother's 105th birth day --
This should have been on
last page -- Sister Mary & self
went to the Tea -- 2 to 6 -- at
Mrs Joseph OConnor & Miss
Olive Morrison -- the niece &
inheritor of Miss Eliz. P. Hall --
in her old home at
Frank street -- it seemed
as if all of Rochesters women
were there -- as we
started home a little after 6 --
the rain & snow began to come --
& very soon a regular tornado
of wind -- which separated us --
Sister May crashed her way home -
at Allen St Bridge -- a whirl took
my spectacles off -- my velvet cloak over
my head -- & I stood -- finally some young
men came along -- one found my glasses --
& one with his sister took me to Keys
Store -- & thence with with Mr. [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a tea and experiencing a wind storm on the way home, which separated her from her sister and caused her to lose her spectacles and velvet cloak.

entries.fullText:
At Home - all day -
Miss Dermett got off a good
lot of letters this day -
Mrs Hair bro't Queen
Stella - who read the
palm of my hands -
also sister May's -
giving very different characteristics
entries.summaryText: Miss Dermett wrote letters, Mrs Hair brought Queen Stella who read Susan's palm, and sister May's palm, giving different characteristics.

entries.fullText:
At home
Little Amie went to her
Church 1st Baptist -
Sister May & I - staid
at home -
entries.summaryText: Susan stayed at home with Sister May while Little Amie went to her church, 1st Baptist.

entries.fullText:
-
2nd meeting of Rochester's
Local Council of Women
this P.M. at 3 o'clock -
entries.summaryText: Attended 2nd meeting of Rochester's Local Council of Women.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sun. Feb 5, 1899 Ther.

lovely & bright & warm
At Home,
wrote in flyleaf of Life & Work of S.B.A.,
To the Gov. & Mrs. Roosevelt-Albany N.Y.
It is with pleasure that I
comply with the request of the P.E.
club of my city & inscribe on this flyleaf
what should be the aim of
every true patriot [?], to establish
perfect equality of rights for women civil
& political - in every state of the Union,
and to make our stars & stripes
over whatever outlying possessions
they may float carry to the people
thereof 'Equal Rights for all'
irrespective of race, color, or sex.
With Highest respect & Admiration
Miss Kate & father Wm. Gleason -
Rev & Mrs Gannett - Miss
Caley - Mrs Nelson & others called
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote in the flyleaf of Life & Work of S.B.A. and sent it to the Governor and Mrs. Roosevelt in Albany, NY. She wrote about the aim of every true patriot to establish perfect equality of rights for women civil and political - in every state of the Union, and to make our stars & stripes over whatever outlying possessions they may float carry to the people thereof 'Equal Rights for all' irrespective of race, color, or sex. She also received visits from Miss Kate & father Wm. Gleason, Rev & Mrs Gannett, Miss Caley, Mrs Nelson & others.

entries.fullText: Ther. at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on Thursday, February 9, 1899.

entries.fullText: Ther. Left Rochester at 6:45 A.M. - Sister Mary going to the R.R. Station with me - mercury clear down - - it was a long, slow day - reached Washington nearer to 9 than 7:15 - found niece Lucy waiting with Mrs Sewall - - but the feeling is forlorn enough - was put in a little front room with bottom of window on level with roof - & only one at that. This was The Arlington too - & $4 a day - & with fire $5. - Rather steep for such a forlorn room Cold & snowy - The Parlor Car was cold for more than half the [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Rochester on Friday, February 10, 1899, and arrived in Washington later than expected. She stayed at The Arlington, which was expensive and had a forlorn room. The Parlor Car was also cold for more than half the trip.

entries.fullText:
At the Arlington --
large meeting of Presidents &
delegates in Parlor A. -- but
no woman looms up for Pres.
of the Council -- as you look
around at the heads of the
20 organizations
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a large meeting of Presidents and delegates at the Arlington, where no woman is considered for President of the Council.

entries.fullText:
In Washington D. C.
at the Arlington
Snowing & blowing all the day --
did not go out to meetings --
brother D.R's only son -- D. R. A. Jr
called in P.M. has been to Mexico
Vera Cruz- Havana & landed in
N. York Friday A.M. -- he is stopping
at the Shoreham
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Washington D.C. at the Arlington, where she stays inside due to the snow. She receives a visit from her nephew, D.R. A. Jr, who has recently returned from traveling to Mexico, Vera Cruz, and Havana.

entries.fullText:
Triennial Council of Women
Church of our Father
five blocks from the
Arlington -- a regular
blizzard -- no one
could walk -- and
the prices of carriages
was Doubled -- all
of us lunched at the
church -- I did
not go back to the
evening session -- very
few, save the friends
from a distance were
at the meetings
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the Triennial Council of Women in Washington D.C. during a blizzard.

entries.fullText:
at Arlington --
got moved into a
back outside room with
but one window - but
had daylight -- the
storm increases -- no
trains going out -
nephew D. R. Jr --
dined with me -- he
is storm bound -- no
trains left Washington
Sunday --
At midnight
this night -- Mrs. Max
Landsberg of Rochester
arrived at Arlington
left home Sunday 8. P.M.
& reached here Tuesday 11. P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is stuck in Arlington during a storm and has dinner with her nephew. Mrs. Max Landsberg arrives at midnight after being stuck in transit for several days.

entries.fullText:
This is S. B. A. 79th Birth day
In Wash. at Arlington
Dear Rachel went
round & asked if any
wished to contribute to a
birth day present to S. B. A.
am handed me $92.00
she is always so very
thoughtful -- but at my
request there was no
public celebration
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's 79th birthday was celebrated in Arlington, Washington. Rachel collected $92.00 for a birthday present, but there was no public celebration.

entries.fullText:
The Council still
in session --
entries.summaryText: The council was still in session.

entries.fullText: In Washington
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was in Washington on February 17, 1899.

entries.fullText:
In Washington
Council closed --
entries.summaryText: Journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was in Washington on February 18, 1899 and that the council was closed.

entries.fullText: Did not go out --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go out on February 19th, 1899.

geographicalLocations: Universalist church cor. of L. & 12th Sts.
entries.fullText:
In Washington --
3d Triennial meeting of
The National Council of
the United States -- in
Universalist church cor. of L. & 12th Sts.
closed yesterday --
Miss Emily Howland
& self went to a club
meeting of colored women
at Mrs. Church Terrells
this evening --
The 8th Congress
of the Daughters of
the American Revolution
opened to-day in old
Albaughs Opera House
Mrs. Daniel Manning
Pres. General!!
entries.summaryText: On February 20th, 1899, Susan B. Anthony was in Washington attending the 3d Triennial meeting of The National Council of the United States. She also went to a club meeting of colored women and the 8th Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution opened that day. She mentions Miss Emily Howland, Mrs. Church Terrells, and Mrs. Daniel Manning, Pres. General.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES. FEB. 21, 1899 Ther.

In Washington
Miss Howland & self
attended the D. A. R.
reception in the
new Corcoran gallery
this evening a perfect jam
of splendid dresses --
Saw there Miss
Adelaide Johnsons
four busts -- Mott, Stanton,
Anthony, Winslow -- all
standing on their red
plush pedestals -
So stiff & stark in
a strait row!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a reception at the new Corcoran gallery in Washington with Miss Howland. She saw four busts by Miss Adelaide Johnsons of Mott, Stanton, Anthony, and Winslow, all standing on their red plush pedestals in a straight row.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sat. Feb. 25, 1899 Ther.

In Phila --
Niece Louise & self went
to 1820 [Deanist?] St -- & dined
with niece Lucy E. & Miss
Shaw -- Dear Rachel
Foster with us -- Dr
also -- After dinner
nephew Burt & Miss
Shaws nieces, Nicolas,
Grace & Eleanor & Graces
sister Lou -- came -- the
girls escorted Miss Shaw
to 4.20 train -- It rained
so that I spent night
with Lucy E. --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined with her nieces and Miss Shaw in Philadelphia, and was accompanied by other family members. She spent the night with Lucy E. due to the rain.

entries.fullText:
In Phila --
went with Louise to
New Century Club -- spoke
there--better-- went home with
Mrs. Emma J. Bartol --
1900 - Spruce St - & Lucy E.
came -- & all dined there
-- then Lucy E went back
to 4716 with us --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to the New Century Club in Phila with Louise and Mrs. Emma J. Bartol and then has dinner with Lucy E.

entries.fullText:
Left Phila on
the 1. P.M. train
for New York --
Lucy & Louise both going
to station -- called on
Mr & Enoch Lewis - the
parents of Mrs. M. T. L. Gannett
Met a cordial welcome
from cousin Samantha
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Phila for New York and visits Mr & Enoch Lewis and cousin Samantha.

entries.fullText:
Went immediately
after dinner - to
Mrs Zabriskies--
Brooklyn - to meet
Federation of Clubs
Program Committee --
Mrs. M. W. Chapman
took me to her home
160 - Hicks St - where
I spent the night -
Mrs. Ann C. Field - &
Rev. John Chadwick
spent evening with us
entries.summaryText: Meeting with Federation of Clubs Program Committee in Brooklyn.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Chapman took
me in her mothers
carriage over to the
World office -- no
direct news from
Oklahoma & Arizona
which means bills
for suffrage lost -
probably --
Lunched & dined
at Mrs. Stantons -- then
went in carriage with
Hattie & Maggie to
Cousin Semanthas - they
went to 7. East 62d st --
to Nannie Miller's birth
day -- I paid toward
carriage - the $1. - that Mrs
S. was to pay for the one she
appropriated for her bible - a
Georgia woman who sent it to
her for N. W. S. A. membership
entries.summaryText: Lunch and dinner at Mrs. Stanton's and attending Nannie Miller's birthday party.

entries.fullText:
Left New York on
11 A.M. train &
reached Hartford Ct.
at 240 P.M --
guest of Mrs Isabella
Beecher Hooker --
several ladies called
in evg -- Mrs
Abby Barke Sheldon
of New Haven there -
also Mrs of
Williamantic a very
bright woman
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left New York and arrived in Hartford Ct. where she stayed with Mrs Isabella Beecher Hooker. She received visits from several ladies including Mrs Abby Barke Sheldon of New Haven and Mrs of Williamantic, a very bright woman.

entries.fullText:
The 30th Ct --W. S.
Core -- at Unity Hall
Mrs. M. S. Howell & self
speakers -- three sessions
with fair audience
though a bad day --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at Unity Hall in Ct along with W. S. Core and Mrs. M. S. Howell. There were three sessions with a fair audience despite the bad weather.

entries.fullText:
In Hartford
at 2.30 P.M. Mrs
Hooker took us
all to the state
capital for a joint
hearing on their
municipal suffrage
bill -- Mrs. Sheldon --
Mrs. Annie C. Fenner
New London -- a very
bright young woman -- &
her sister Mrs Ella S. Bennett
of Willimantic -- spoke --
bright also
entries.summaryText: Attended a joint hearing on municipal suffrage bill in Hartford with Mrs. Hooker, Mrs. Sheldon, Mrs. Annie C. Fenner, and Mrs. Ella S. Bennett.

entries.fullText:
Left Hartford at 11.
with Mrs. Hookers
daughter Alice Day --
Mrs. T. Elizabeth wife Wm
Richardson - and niece
of Eliza Combs Wolcott
widow of Frank Wolcott
died this day --
Went to cousin
Semanthas --
entries.summaryText: Left Hartford with Mrs. Hooker's daughter Alice Day, Mrs. T. Elizabeth, and niece of Eliza Combs Wolcott. Went to cousin Semanthas.

entries.fullText:
at no 10 - East 68th st --
- Cousin sent me in
carriage -- 1st to call
on Charlotte B. Wilbour
at the Savoy -- took
her in carriage to Mrs
Stantons -- where she had
tell Mrs S.of her boy Theodore
in Paris -- then at 12.00
took in Hattie - & went
to 220 West 77th st -- Mrs W --
going back to the Savoy --
Mrs Gaffney had 6 or 8
to lunch --. She read us
Mrs. Sewalls letters or Comment
- & Harriot [?] from
London -- a good deal
mixed I should say
cousin S. came & took me on
lovely drive
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits several people in New York and has lunch with Mrs. Gaffney.

entries.fullText:
Went to Friends Meeting
at Rutherford Place--
15th St & 2d Avenue--
&
preacher [Mcl?]
from Canaday--
then spent P.M. evening
at home--Mrs Day &
her daughter called
though it did rain--
Cousin Geo. Vails
oldest daughter Louise
Vail Wakeman there--[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a Friends Meeting and spends the rest of the day at home with visitors.

entries.fullText:
Left New York
on 8.20 - Empire State --
& reached home at 2.43 --
P.M -- a lovely ride
found sister Mary all
O. K. -- except her
forehead -- very red
A huge pile
of letters -- appalled
me --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left New York and arrived home to find her sister Mary with a red forehead and a huge pile of letters.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home.

entries.fullText: Miss Sally L Bennett stenographer & typewriter came this A.M. so I began to read the pile. Brother Daniel A, arrived at 10 A.M. from New York -- had been to Washington to get promotion for his Maud's husband - Liet. Lewis Koehler --
entries.summaryText: Miss Sally L Bennett, Brother Daniel A, and Liet. Lewis Koehler were mentioned. Miss Sally L Bennett came over and Brother Daniel A arrived from New York after being in Washington to get a promotion for his Maud's husband, Liet. Lewis Koehler.

entries.fullText: Cold & snowy & blowy -- made wood fire in back parlor grate & sat down to visit -- there was no going about town
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about spending time with her brother D.R. at home due to the cold and snowy weather.

entries.fullText: -- still cold & dreary outside but very pleasant within -- almost never had so quiet & pleasant a visit with brother D. R. -- always in a hurry -- with both of us but this is leisurely
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about spending another day with her brother D.R. at home, enjoying a quiet and pleasant visit.

entries.fullText: Brother D. R. A. took the 2.30 P.M-train -- severe snow & blow -- so neither Mary nor self went to station -- a cab came for him -- It seems to me we never had so quiet & long a visit from or with our brother --
entries.summaryText: Brother D. R. A. visits Susan B. Anthony at home during a snowstorm.
Susan B. Anthony writes nothing on this day.

entries.fullText:
Working away at
reading the file
of letters --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and working on reading a file of letters.

entries.fullText:
Mailed article on
International Council
to night -- to the
N. Y. World --
Mr. W. Van Benthuysen
Ed in Chief -- who was
editor of brother D. R.s
Leavenworth Times years
ago then of the
Chicago Tribune &
now of the N. Y. World
I wrote him
about sendg Mrs Hair
to London as special
correspondent for the [?]
[?] International Council
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and mails an article to the N. Y. World about the International Council. She also writes to Mr. W. Van Benthuysen about sending Mrs. Hair to London as a special correspondent for the International Council.

entries.fullText:
At home
Sister Mary & self
called this evening
at Mrs. L.C. Smiths
The first & only
call I have made
since getting home
this time
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary made their first and only call since getting home at Mrs. L.C. Smiths.

entries.fullText:
At home --
Sister M. & self
called at the Dr
Jonas Jones- home
-- on Miss Jones &
her Toronto sister -
Mrs Dundas -- &
talked over womens
[?] in Canada --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary visited Dr. Jonas Jones' home and talked about women's issues in Canada with Miss Jones and her sister Mrs. Dundas.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from March 25, 1899.

entries.fullText:
at home
Wrote letters all day --
at 5 P.M. sister Mary
& self called at
Mrs. Eliza Combs Wolcott's --
met Hope [A???] --

Got the N. Y. Sun
with Mrs. Harper's
article -- also the N. Y.
World with S. B. A's on
International Council
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from March 26, 1899. Susan B. Anthony wrote letters and visited Mrs. Eliza Combs Wolcott with her sister Mary. She also met someone named Hope [A???] and read articles about herself and the International Council in the N. Y. Sun and N. Y. World.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester for
Geneva -- Ontario Co --
at 9.40 -- guest
of Mrs. E. S. Miller --
Her coachman John
drove up to station
just as I landed
from the train --
Found Mrs Miller & daughter
Anne F. -- with Gertrude
Walter - & Mr Walter Chemiss --
of no .7 . East 62nd St - New York --
also Harriot Stanton Blatch
& daughter Nora -- all
arrived the last week -
-- I tried to get a sleep but
failed -- had a splendid
audience in Collins Hall
- but alas had not a free
minute in the whole hour --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Rochester to Geneva, Ontario Co. and meets with Mrs. E. S. Miller, Gertrude Walter, Mr. Walter Chemiss, Harriot Stanton Blatch, and Nora. She had a speech at Collins Hall.

entries.fullText:
Left Geneva at
3:42 -- called a half
hour at Cousin
Lucius Homes -- he
seemed bright -- & the
girls Nettie & Nina-- also -
-- but the thought
of last night's speech -
& the all-night's sleeplessness-
is like a
nightmare over me --

Mrs Hawley Bucklin
of Ithica spent night
with us -- an earnest
bright woman
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Geneva and visits Cousin Lucius Homes. Mrs. Hawley Bucklin of Ithica spends the night with them.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on March 29, 1899.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on March 30, 1899.

entries.fullText:
Sister Marys 72nd birthday --
also that of nephew
Frank & Ella Dix Moshers
oldest daughter Florence -- who
is 14 years old to day --
A letter from Cousin
Ira Howe's step daughter
Mrs Adelaide Jones
Ottawa -- PM
entries.summaryText: Celebration of Sister Mary's and Florence's birthdays and a letter from Cousin Ira Howe's step daughter Mrs Adelaide Jones.

entries.fullText:
At home --
Dear Mother's passing
on to the invisible - was
19 years ago this day --
The memories came
back many of them --
Mrs Hallowell -- Mrs.
Willis, Georgia Post Dennis &
husband - with. Houts wife -
Dr. & Mrs Sanford - & a
Miss Rogers from Prince
Edwards Island -- and Mrs
Boardman from Toledo -
with sundry others called in
the evening -- I am too
heavy spirited to be
of any use --
entries.summaryText: Memories of her mother's passing and visitors at home.

entries.fullText:
At home-but
letter from Mrs Stanton
written yesterday-April 3
19th anniversary of dear [Walters?]
death- says- "now do not
get the big head & think
anything from you will do"-
which comes of her Harriots
telling of my failure of a talk
at Geneva- I was crushed
with the fact before-but
to having the cause ascribed
to "the big head" is a blow
too cruel-- when I always
feel my incapacity to make what
may be called an address-- I
can when in best conditions- make
a few remarks- but oh me- a
sustained speech- was, is &
I expect ever will be an impossibility
with me- alas, alas- that
the friends will forever press me into
making a failure!!
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton wrote a letter to Susan B. Anthony on April 3, 1899. Susan B. Anthony talks about her failure of a talk at Geneva and how she feels about making speeches.

entries.fullText:
At home,
Queen Stella the
gipsy- had her
performance- for
benefit of Kindergarten
--dear Mrs. Linn. The
Clar. of Comm. a
total failure--
entries.summaryText: Queen Stella the gipsy had a performance at Susan B. Anthony's home for the benefit of Kindergarten. The Clar. of Comm. was a total failure.

entries.dateText:
Wea SAT. APRIL 8, 1899 Ther.
at Home
entries.fullText:
Wea SAT. APRIL 8, 1899 Ther.
at Home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated April 8, 1899, written at home.

entries.dateText:
Wea. SUN. APRIL 9, 1899 Ther.
At home
Sister Mary & self
went to church - Mr
Gannett preached on
or rather talked on proposed
Liberal religionists
Convention - for New York
entries.fullText:
Wea. SUN. APRIL 9, 1899 Ther.
At home
Sister Mary & self
went to church - Mr
Gannett preached on
or rather talked on proposed
Liberal religionists
Convention - for New York
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated April 9, 1899, written at home. Sister Mary and the author went to church and listened to Mr. Gannett talk about the proposed Liberal religionists Convention for New York.

entries.fullText:
at home-
dictating &c--all day-
quite a large number
called at evening - Mr
& Mrs John M Thayer
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home dictating and a large number of people visited her in the evening, including Mr. and Mrs. John M Thayer.

entries.fullText:
at home
At eveing called
on Mrs (?) Boardman
Smith Front Street--
& then on Mrs Hallowell--
- met there quite a lot
who hand been at Tea
with her-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home and in the evening visited Mrs. (?) Boardman Smith on Front Street and then Mrs. Hallowell where she met a lot of people who had been at tea with her.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from April 12, 1899, where Susan B. Anthony writes that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
At Home--
[P?] letter answering--
went to Dr. Requas he
filled right eye tooth & the
one back of it--to my
distress the second one back
of it--which he filled the
Monday previous--began
swelling again at the root--
he lanced the gum--& said
it would be the last of it &c
but my faith was gone--
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from April 13, 1899, where Susan B. Anthony writes about going to the dentist and her lack of faith in the treatment.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & girl Annie
cleaning the house--
while I am agonizing
over getting points to talk on
at Grand Rapids--
Sister Mary & self went
to Lyceum Theatre--to
Rings Karnival--for
benefit of girls home--
Dancing--dancing--galore
entries.summaryText: Susan's sister Mary and a girl named Annie cleaned the house while Susan was preparing for a talk in Grand Rapids. Later, Susan and Mary went to the Lyceum Theatre for a benefit event.

entries.fullText:
At home--
Bright lovely Spring day--
entries.summaryText: Susan spent a lovely spring day at home.

entries.fullText: Niece Louise H. Mosher James arrived 9.30 A.M. from Cleveland--& from Duluth where she spent 5 weeks with her brother Wendell--It rained & snowed--so all staid at home--she went to Sunday school & bro't home the mail--In P.M. Sister Mary & I, went to the [L?]ahor Lyceum & heard Mrs [Newman?] speak on woman & her relations to [government?]----Ella Dix Mosher & 3 children came down--after Louise & self had [bed?] & sleep--then L. went home with them
entries.summaryText: Louise H. Mosher James arrived from Cleveland and Duluth, Mary and Susan went to the Labor Lyceum, and Ella Dix Mosher and her children came to visit.

entries.fullText:
Tea at Mrs Greenleafs
Miss Shaw to call-
entries.summaryText: Tea at Mrs Greenleafs with Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText:
at Home
Brother Merritt's 65th birth
day-
entries.summaryText: Celebrated Brother Merritt's 65th birthday at home.

entries.fullText:
Little Eliza's 67th birth day--
Poor mother's first great heart sorrow
was two years later when the little one
died
Mrs. Colby arrived at
9 P.M.--bright & cheery
came over Northern Central--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Little Eliza's birthday and Mrs. Colby's visit.

entries.fullText:
Clara B. Colby--speaks
at Unitarian Church--on The
work of woman in the [?]
Went to Church--Mr. Gannett
spoke of Extinction of [?]--
extinction of civilizations--extinction
of religions--and took the
latter--showing from the
real germ of truth survived
& was embodied in the
new religion--while the
name--the forms as passed
out of existence--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Clara B. Colby's speech and Mr. Gannett's sermon at church.

entries.fullText:
Spent morning packing for G. R.
Sister Mary went down town
bought R.R. ticket to Buffalo checked
baggage--drew check on Safe of [?]
Mrs. Colby & self took 2.25 train
west--sister Mary going to station--
reached Buffalo to find no sleeper
could be had till 11.10 at Detroit--
so settled down to a six hours
sit up,--when Mariam M. Chapman
Antoinette Brown & Mrs. Henretta
Danker & others--who had to go on to
The Falls to see me & stop over
on their tickets & their return to
Buffalo at Gilmore Hotel--for
business meeting of N.Y. State [Lt?] Com.
on the morrow--while I rolled
on--had a lovely glimpse of
the Falls--once more--took supper
for a dollar & whiled away an
hour--& in due season was
ferried across the Detroit River
& safely in bed on sleeper
for [grand ] departs
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Buffalo and has a lovely glimpse of the Falls before continuing her journey to Detroit.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Warwick Hotel
Grand Rapids Mich--6 A.M.
Rachel Foster Ames & Nicholas
Shaw arrived a few minutes later
from Philadelphia--
Mrs. & Mrs. Ketcham soon called
everything promises well for the
Convention--warm & bright
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Grand Rapids, Michigan for a convention and is greeted by Rachel Foster Ames, Nicholas Shaw, and Mrs. Ketcham.

entries.fullText: Business Com. meeting all the day & evening - in my room at Hotel Warwith all present but Mrs McCullock -
entries.summaryText: Business committee meeting in Grand Rapids with all present except Mrs. McCullock.

entries.fullText: 31st used to be annual Washington Con - now - Annual Con. N.A.W.S.A. Ex. com. in A.M.
entries.summaryText: Annual convention of N.A.W.S.A. Executive Committee held in the morning.

entries.fullText:
31st Annual Meeting N.W.S.A.
at Grand Rapids
entries.summaryText: 31st Annual Meeting of N.W.S.A. in Grand Rapids.

entries.fullText:
Left the Warwick
this A. M. and went
to Mrs John Blodgets -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left the Warwick and went to visit Mrs John Blodgets.

entries.fullText:
At Mr Blodgetts--
Mrs Sewall--Rachel--Miss
Shaw & Miss Bates came
& we held a National
Council meeting--& Mrs S.
drew up the Peace
Conference Resolution--
In P.M. I tried hard
to get a napp--but was
to anxious--at 7.30 Mr &
Mrs B. took me to Baptist
Church--& there was a packed
audience--mostly bonnets--so
it was a perfect flowery garden
I look at from the pulpit--the
Pastor asked them take off their
hats--I succeeded better
than I feared--showing them
that woman's moral influence
must be backed with political
power of ballot to be effective
entries.summaryText: Attended a National Council meeting at Mr. Blodgett's house with Mrs. Sewall, Rachel, Miss Shaw, and Miss Bates. Went to the Baptist Church with Mr. and Mrs. B. where Susan spoke about the importance of political power of ballot for women's moral influence.

entries.fullText:
Grand Rapids Con--
S.B.A. to speak this evening on
'The Power of the ballot in Municipal
Governments'
entries.summaryText: Susan is scheduled to speak in Grand Rapids about the power of the ballot in municipal governments.

entries.fullText:
31st National Con at
Grand Rapids--
Mrs Blodgett gave a splendid
Luncheon this noon to our
B.C. & several others--
making twelve in all
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the 31st National Convention in Grand Rapids and has lunch with Mrs. Blodgett and others.

entries.fullText:
Report of Congressional Com--
in A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the National Women's Suffrage Association Convention and hears a report from the Congressional Committee in the morning.

entries.fullText:
At G.R. all of this
day--three sessions--our
Business Com. was in
session in Rachels room
at the Monmuth Hotel--
Mrs Bissell &
daughter were at lunch
at Mrs. Blodgetts--I
was very much pleased
with her--She has not only
her [?] carpet sweeper
facility in G.R. but one in
Canada & another in
England--
Miss Shaw left early
this A.M. to speak at Hillsdale--
tomorrow night at Hartford
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day in Grand Rapids, including a Business Committee session and meeting with Mrs. Blodgett and Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText:
Grand Rapids
Mrs. J. Blodgett took
Mrs. Catt & me out to
Mrs. Smiths Hot [?]
the finest in G.R.
Left G.R. at 11 P.M.
all our girls left
before me--
Miss Shaw was up
after lecture at Hartford--&
sat in common car last
half of the night--& met
me on leaving in Chicago--
so we went together to
Mrs. Gross'--whose
man met us--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Mrs. Smith's Hot and leaving Grand Rapids with Miss Shaw to go to Mrs. Gross' in Chicago.

entries.fullText: Mrs Coonly Ward--gives reception to Miss Shaw inviting Chicago 400--[excepting?] the Antis" to meet her--a fine company & Miss Shaw's speech convention & good [?]--all were delighted--at 5:30 I left & Mrs Gross sent me to Palmer House to see Mrs. Catt, Miss Clay & Mrs. Day--
entries.summaryText: Mrs Coonly Ward gives a reception to Miss Shaw in Chicago inviting Chicago 400, excepting the Antis. Miss Shaw's speech was convention and good. Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Catt, Miss Clay, and Mrs. Day at Palmer House.

entries.fullText: Went over & took breakfast with cousin Albert Dickinson--then back to lunch with Mrs Gross--then at 3 P.M. to the Auditorium--to great patriotic mass meeting--Wm Dudley Foulke main speaker--Miss Shaw at home all day--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has breakfast with cousin Albert Dickinson, lunch with Mrs. Gross, and attends a patriotic mass meeting at the Auditorium with Wm Dudley Foulke as the main speaker. Miss Shaw stays at home all day in Chicago.

entries.fullText: Drove to 157 Honore St--to see Mr Hedenberg--about memorials of 1891--& found he had burned all--two years ago--at 2 P.M. Miss Shaw & self went to Masonic Temple--Corinthian Hall--to be initiated into American Corps of Army relief women--& large gathering from all parts of the state--Left C. at 11.30 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Visited Mr Hedenberg and found out he had burned all memorials of 1891. Went to Masonic Temple to be initiated into American Corps of Army relief women.

entries.fullText: On Mich. Central R.R. a freight train smash up a few miles east of Ypsilanti--so waited at Y. five hours--took hack & drove to town & called on dear & feeble Amelia Willard--was 78--last January--so is one year younger than I am--This long visit put us over to [?] A.D.--instead of 8.40 this evening to reach Rochester--
entries.summaryText: Waited for five hours due to a train smash up. Visited Amelia Willard and arrived late to Rochester.

entries.fullText:
At Home--
Sister getting ready to
leave for London &
the Continent--
Miss Shaw & self
arrived at station at
2.30 this A.M.--got
carriage home--& were
in bed by 4. oclock--
&
sister Mary had us up
& at breakfast by 7.20--
entries.summaryText: Sister is leaving for London and the Continent. Miss Shaw and Susan B. Anthony arrived home at 2:30 AM and were in bed by 4:00 AM. Sister Mary had them up and at breakfast by 7:20 AM.

entries.fullText:
Went to Station
with sister Mary for the
9.05 train--going to New
York--to cousin Emily
Clark Griggs--41 East 10th St--
the rain pouring--so
got carriage--much to
her dismay--told her to
ruin her new & beautiful
gray suit would waste
lots more money--
At 2 P.M. I went
station with Miss Shaw
who was to speak at Eden &c
entries.summaryText: Accompanied sister Mary to the station in the pouring rain. Susan B. Anthony went to the station with Miss Shaw at 2:00 PM, who was to speak at Eden.

entries.fullText:
--
at home --
and the house
fearfully lonely with
sister Mary gone
out of it -- even
for a few months --
what would it be
if it were for all time
& I were to be left alone?
entries.summaryText: Susan is feeling lonely at home without her sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary to sail for
London - on Atlantic
Transportation Line Steamer
Marquette --- Dr & Mrs
Sanford & Madeline -- D. M. A.,
wife & Gertude going with her --
Letter, written yesterday --
came this A. M -- alas a
funny one from cousin
Emily Lash Griggs --
Mrs Clara B. Polly
arrived from Detroit at
8.40 -- Little Anna & I
called at Mrs. L. C. Smythe's
& bro't home sets of The Life-
entries.summaryText: Susan's sister Mary is sailing to London on the Atlantic Transportation Line Steamer Marquette. Susan receives a funny letter from cousin Emily Lash Griggs. Mrs. Clara B. Polly arrives from Detroit and Susan visits Mrs. L. C. Smythe's and brings home sets of The Life-.

entries.fullText:
Went to Church --Mrs
Colby - also - Mr Gannett
text -- Co-education -- &
spoke of it the home,
school & every/where save
in the government -- I
told him of his failure &
he looked so sad that
I felt sorry for doing it--

Mrs C; & self went -- to Old
Auditorium Central church
to hear Rev Annis Ford
Eastman--before the Loyal
Legion--a small audience
--too bad
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Mrs. Colby and Mr. Gannett. Discussed co-education and its lack of implementation in government. Attended a small audience with Mrs. Colby to hear Rev Annis Ford Eastman before the Loyal Legion.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Colly spoke this
evenig in Lake Avenue
Baptist Church -- for
Loyal Legion -- very
very few present - &
she hesitated & labored
all the way through --
altogether it made me
shudder over next
Sunday at the Buck
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Colly spoke at Lake Avenue Baptist Church for the Loyal Legion, but very few were present and she struggled through her speech.

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs Polly took the 6:45
train for Washington
entries.summaryText: Mrs Polly took the 6:45 train for Washington

entries.fullText:
At home
Ster Mary getting
into the very middle of
the Atlantic ---
at - 8. P. M. Miss
Miss Waldo & Miss Darwin
called with carriage &
took me to the Lyceum
to annual testimonial of the
Press Association -- they
were very sweet & [?] & nice
music ditto
entries.summaryText: Ster Mary getting into the very middle of the Atlantic. Miss Waldo & Miss Darwin called with carriage & took me to the Lyceum to annual testimonial of the Press Association -- they were very sweet & [?] & nice music ditto

entries.fullText:
At home
Took article to Dem. & Chron. office from Mrs. Colby--found Miss Tomlinson there--Mrs. Hair gone to the Press Musical Festival--

Rainy all day--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and took an article to the Dem. & Chron. office from Mrs. Colby. She found Miss Tomlinson there and Mrs. Hair had gone to the Press Musical Festival. It was rainy all day.

entries.fullText:
At home
Letter from English Suffrage [?] to speak for them June 29th--

In P.M. called on Mrs Fulham--came back home dressed & went to tea-dinner with Emma B. Sweet--to see her mother--Mrs. Biddlecom of Maredon--the daughter of Daniel Lapham--son of my Grand mother Anthonys brother Abraham Lapham--in their new house--Audubon street away out in Brighton--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from English Suffrage to speak for them on June 29th. She called on Mrs. Fulham in the afternoon and then went to tea-dinner with Emma B. Sweet to see her mother, Mrs. Biddlecom of Maredon, who is the daughter of Daniel Lapham, son of Susan's grandmother's brother Abraham Lapham. They were in their new house on Audubon street in Brighton.

entries.fullText: cloudy & showery & cold--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the weather being cloudy, showery, and cold.

entries.fullText: Brick Church--2 P.M. for Young Peoples Loyal Legion--moral [?] [be?] Political Power
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about attending a meeting at Brick Church for the Young Peoples Loyal Legion, where they discussed moral and political power.

entries.fullText: Went over to Mrs. Fullams for tea last [?] of dresses
entries.summaryText: Went to Mrs. Fullam's for tea and saw dresses.

entries.fullText:
At Home--
Went to church--Mr. Gannett
preached Decoration day Sermon.
--that civil war had holy
purpose--but Phillipian only
grasping greed for [everything?]
&c--I told him it was worthy
Parker Pillsbury--of whom
he more & more reminds me
--Then to Sarah H. Willis
to dinner--Mary Hallowell
Mrs. Lucy B. Smith & nieces &
Georgie Post & husband Mr. Bemis
there-- nice visit--at 3 P.M.
Mary H. went with me to hear
Mrs. H. B. Montgomery at 1st M.E. Church
on some methods of Temperance &c
then hurried home to pack trunks
--but Mrs. M. came & made a long
call--then came Ella Bix Mosher
sister Florence & children--I simply
had to excuse myself--& set
about getting myself together
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church and has dinner with friends. She also attends a Temperance meeting and packs her trunks.

entries.fullText:
Little Annie E. Dann
left house no. 17 Madison St--
at nearly 8 A.M. to take train
for London--Canada--& I left
at 8.20 in carriage--Mrs. Cook
shutting the front door for me
took basket with papers, silver
&c to Security Bank--for Mrs.
Emma B. Sweet to put
in deposit until sister Mary
& I return from Europe--
Found Mr & Mrs Gannett
at the station--& the train
15 minutes late--so took a
full breath & had a nice chat
& loving good bye from them
They were much amused to
see & hear each of the Station
men give their hearty God bless you
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sees Annie E. Dann off to London and Canada and has a chat with Mr. and Mrs. Gannett at the station.

entries.fullText: Cousin Samantha took me driving in P.M.--called on Mrs Stanton--Mrs Chapman Catt called & was at dinner--went to Station with her--going to Boston--had a good talk with Mary G. Hay--In evening nephew A.A. Mosher sister Hannah's oldest--called--took supper--Mrs C.B. Wilholm & son called--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with family and friends in New York, including a visit with Mary G. Hay and dinner with Mrs. Chapman Catt.

entries.fullText: Cousin S. sent her Crillie with me to Mrs Stanton's--where I lunched--listened her word read aloud two hours--then cousin S. called & took me a two hours drive to Grants Tomb & Morning Side Park--lovey & restful--Somehow my farewell visit, to Mrs Stanton left a sad feeling--very unusual! Cousin Geo O. Vails oldest daughter Louise Wakeman husband & son George here to supper--& in even Louis Lapham & son Roger--just from summer harvest at [Lenox?] [?]--called--later great nephew Dr. Henry A. Baker--sister Guelma & Aaron McLeans eldest grand-son called--full of Baker Optimism--but how much based on solid truth is the question & said he had $590. in Bank--that his sister Guelma was engaged to go on the stage with Mojeska!!--Mrs. Wakeman's daughter Annette graduate this noon--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with family and friends in New York, including a visit to Grants Tomb and Morning Side Park with Cousin S. and a farewell visit with Mrs. Stanton that leaves her feeling sad.

entries.fullText:
In New York--at Cousin Samantha
Vail Laphams-10, East 68th St--
Cousin took me to Arnold & Constables
& presented me with 3 sets of lovely
silk Union suits & two pair black
silk gloves--Then she set me down
at 40 West 59th Street to call on Mrs.
Charlotte Behee Wilbour--who has now
returned to New York to live--after a
good chat she gave me a little box
with 8 gold pieces--$10--each=$40--
it was indeed lovely of her!
Very warm--at 2. Cousin Ellen
Hoxie Squires & niece Louise Mosher
James came for a 2 hours call--
at 4--went to bed & had a good
nap--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Cousin Samantha Vail Laphams in New York and receives gifts of silk Union suits and black silk gloves. She also visits Mrs. Charlotte Behee Wilbour and receives a box of gold pieces. Later, Cousin Ellen Hoxie Squires and niece Louise Mosher James come for a visit.

entries.fullText:
Shaw, Foster Avery, Catt--&c to
Lunch with Mrs. Jeffrey--new [?]
333 West 77th St--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has lunch with Shaw, Foster Avery, Catt, and others at Mrs. Jeffrey's new place on 333 West 77th St.

entries.fullText:
New York--for
London on steamer
Menominie--Atlantic
Newport Line--Leave
from Pier 39--foot of
West Houston street--
[Paid?] 125 for state room--112
[was?] tax booking 2/127 (63 1/2--each
for Nora Blatch & self--for
state room no. 3--$63.50--
Cousin Samantha V. Lapham
sent 4 of us Shaw, Foster Avery,
Lucy & self to steamer & found there
Nephew Arthur Mosher--great nephew
Dr. Henry A. Baker & niece Louise
to see us off--weather delightful--
walked--talked--ate the
meals & took two hours sleep
in P.M.--[?th] [?]
Len Mosher both to [stersmth?]
was for Sunday A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her journey from New York to London on the Menominie steamer, including details about the state room, the people she traveled with, and the weather.

entries.fullText:
On Board Menominie
Sea smooth as need be--
Everybody skipping about--
not a sea-sick person had of
tables filled with [?] victuals
90 women & 18 men--with
2 bath tubs & 8 closets for 90--
and 8 wash basins--five closest &
3 bath rooms for the 18--
Rev Anna H. Shaw--Lucy E.
Anthony--Harriet & Alice Purvis--
Emily Howland, Mrs. Gross, Dr
H[ochett?] Stevenson, E. [?] Howard
Nora Blatch & self at our table
Wife & two daughters of Senator
Hawley of Ct--12 Canadaigua
women going to International Council--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her experience on board the Menominie steamer, including details about the passengers, the facilities, and the people she dined with.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
delightful
Menominie
--nothing could be
finer--everybody up &
stirring--Splendid bath
at 7--breakfast at 8--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes a delightful day in Menominie, with everyone up and stirring, and a splendid bath and breakfast.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
Still pleasant &
calm
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony notes that the weather is still pleasant and calm.

entries.fullText:
A ship in
distance - our ship
stopped & the Doctor
taken in boat - their
Captain was very ill with
pneumonia.
entries.summaryText: The Doctor was taken in a boat to another ship where their Captain was very ill with pneumonia.

entries.fullText:
-In the evening with Misses Manning's
daughters played a song &
Mr. Kline played on his shells - &
then Miss Wainwrights - a bride
for only a week - husband
Mr. Roberts - called me
out for a talk & gave Miriam
Gendries Con. story of 1852 - &
after it Mrs. M. gave
Juliet's last scene - beautiful
entries.summaryText: Played music with friends and heard stories from Mr. Roberts and Mrs. M.

geographicalLocations: the wreck of the S.S. Paris
entries.fullText:
On ship Menominee -
about 4 P.M. Saw [?]
the wreck of the S.S. Paris
high on the rocks a little in
front of the wreck of the
Mohegan - near the Manacles
- how the Paris could get
there in broad - day - light -
no one can imagine -
entries.summaryText: Saw the wreck of the S.S. Paris on the rocks near the Manacles.

entries.cityOrState: on steamer Menominee, Thames River, Liverpool landing station, York Road Hotel
entries.fullText:
On steamer Menominee -
- passed through straits of Dover
- & made longest detour to
get into the Thames River - then
got aground in the mud -
& passengers & baggage had to
be transferred to tug to be
taken to some place - & thence
train to Liverpool landing station
thence carriages to hotels -
- found Mr Blatch at landing -
- So felt sure of company forward
- he took a four wheeler with
trunks to Waterloo Station - me a
cab with the satchels to Temple
Hotel to find no room - so we
drove to Waterloo - & then waited
a long time before Mr B. came with
trunks - then to York Road Hotel -
where they had one room with two
beds - so Mr B had to sleep on
sofa - with chairs in front - it
was near midnight before we
were settled & in bed -
A most tedious day - though
bright & sunny - a fearfully cold
penetrating wind -
entries.summaryText: Had a tedious day traveling by steamer, train, and carriages with Mr. Blatch, encountered various issues and ended up at York Road Hotel with one room and two beds.

entries.fullText:
Left York Road Hotel at
9 a.m. for Basingstoke - with
Mr. B & Nora Slanton Blatch -
found Harriet at station -
- a bright sunny day but cool
in the shade - found
letters from Mrs. Seargent P
[?] Bristol - Mrs. [?]
Miller - Mrs Garrett [?] - &
Mrs. Blemour - feel lost apart
from our W. S. party
Took a mile drive
in the
country in the
P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from York Road Hotel to Basingstoke with Mr. B and Nora Slanton Blatch. She meets Harriet at the station and receives letters from several people. She takes a drive in the country in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
At Basingstoke
Trying to write letters
got of a half dozzen
and took a drive with
Hattie & her new horse.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day in Basingstoke trying to write letters and takes a drive with Hattie and her new horse.

entries.fullText: Mrs. Millicent Garrett Fawcett came at 12:20 to luncheon & returned to London at [2?] - She seems not to take in the Council idea - or if she does - not to like it and not willing to cooperate with it -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Millicent Garrett Fawcett came to lunch but seems unwilling to cooperate with the Council idea.

entries.fullText: A gray windy day - Package from Cousin Samantha Lapham - via American Express - first [?] were from Mrs. Smart - all is well there at Rochester - Wrote several letters one to dear Mrs. Stanford on her limiting numbers of girls in University to [five?] hundred while giving no limit to the boys - the alumni fear College will not hold its own in athletic contests because of [?] girls - the male alumni - quite likely
entries.summaryText: Received a package from Cousin Samantha Lapham and wrote a letter to Mrs. Stanford about the limit on girls in the University.

entries.fullText: Wea. Wed. June 21, 1899 Ther.

entries.cityOrState: London - St Ermins Hotel - Westminister - S.W
