people: Rev Anna H. Shaw - niece Lucy E.
entries.fullText:
Left Basingstoke - 11:20 -
reached London - St Ermins
Hotel - Westminister - S.W - 12:30 -
- Rev Anna H. Shaw - niece Lucy E.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Basingstoke to London and meets with Rev Anna H. Shaw and her niece Lucy E.

entries.fullText:
Guest of Harriot Stanton Blatch
at the Pioneer Club - No. 5. -
Grafton st - Piccadilly
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was a guest of Harriot Stanton Blatch at the Pioneer Club in London, England located at No. 5. Grafton st - Piccadilly on June 25, 1899.

entries.fullText:
National Suffrage Societies Great Britain
invite me speak at Queens Hall
at 8 P.M. this day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was invited to speak at Queens Hall by the National Suffrage Societies Great Britain.

entries.fullText:
Society American Women in
London - invites me to luncheon
at the Cecil Hotel - this day - sent
it to Hattie Stanton to answer -
entries.summaryText: Invitation to a luncheon at the Cecil Hotel in London from the Society American Women.

entries.fullText:
London - spent
all the forenoon
At 3:45 too train to
Windsor Castle - stood in
hot & gloomy sun a whole hour
before the gate was opened to let
us through & file along the drive
way - to see the Queen ride
down & have to each
sit along the lane -
after that we were shown
through the Castle & served
tea in the great St. Georges
Hall - but a tired lot
we were -
entries.summaryText: Visited Windsor Castle and saw the Queen.

entries.fullText:
Spent four hours
10 to 2 in basement of hotel
in Business meeting - Lady
Ballerson & Lady Sherdeen
present - the latter stopping
until all was done -
Mrs. Linwall & self took
the :21 train for [?]
Prince of Wales receiving the
troops - so we missed it &
took 5:20 train - found
Mrs. Fenwick Miller & her
two daughters in their
little home - we were at
once conducted to the gardens
for tea - it was after ten
when we rose from the
dinner table - very nice
& quiet - after that
two weeks of noise & bustle
of Ironcar.
entries.summaryText: Attended a business meeting and visited Mrs. Fenwick Miller's home for tea.

geographicalLocations: The Priory of Lady Henry Somersets
entries.fullText: At Reigate - at Mrs. Fenwick Miller's & her two daughters - took a long country drive in morning - saw The Priory of Lady Henry Somersets - & the little cottage at the gate in which Frances Willard spent many pleasant months during her illness - Mrs. Sewall with me & we returned to London on 9:21 train. It was late - so we did not reach St. Ermins until 11:45 tired & sleepy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Reigate, sees The Priory of Lady Henry Somersets and the little cottage where Frances Willard spent time during her illness, and returns to London with Mrs. Sewall.

entries.fullText: At St. Ermins Spent five hours from 11 to 4 - again in business meeting of Council - Miss Shaw & Lucy E left for their Riegate trip going toward Oxford - The delegates are nearing all leaving the hotel - this closed business meetings Cousin Emily this P.M. presented me $100 - in gold - & wished me to get a long nice winter cloak with it - It is lovely of her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a business meeting of Council at St. Ermins, Miss Shaw and Lucy E leave for their Riegate trip, and Cousin Emily presents Susan with $100 to buy a winter cloak.

entries.fullText: Called at Ambassador Choates at 5:20 - Mrs. Gross - cousin Emily clash Mrs Sewall & others then to Mrs Griffins met Pres. American Society of Women
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Ambassador Choates and Mrs. Griffins, meeting with Mrs. Gross, cousin Emily clash, Mrs Sewall, and the President of the American Society of Women.

entries.fullText:
Dr. Stevenson sailed
today.
entries.summaryText: Dr. Stevenson sailed today.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Gross drove and[?]
out to call on the[?] [5?]
little violinist - Leonora
Jackson
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Gross drove to visit little violinist Leonora Jackson.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Sewall & self
took dinner with Mrs
Fisher Unwin - that is
with Jane Cobden - the
daughter of Richard Cobden
- in the very same house
she lived in 16 years ago - So
she has simply taken her
husband into her own house
& home - they seem very
happy-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Sewall had dinner with Mrs. Fisher Unwin (Jane Cobden) and her husband, who now live in the same house Jane lived in 16 years ago. Jane is the daughter of Richard Cobden and seems happy with her husband.

entries.fullText: A letter from dear cousin Emily Clark who was still at Hotel Clarence at Leddington had been down with one of those spells
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Emily Clark who is staying at Hotel Clarence in Leddington and is unwell.

entries.fullText:
St. Ermins
at 11:30 A.M. attend
conference local government
society - 17 Tothill street
Westminster S.W.
Miss. Annie Leigh Browne sec'y
entries.summaryText: Attended conference for local government society in Westminster S.W. with Miss. Annie Leigh Browne as secretary.

entries.fullText:
St. Ermins
Sister Mary & the Sanfords
sail for home today-
Lunch - Montefiore
tea Broadly Road
reception at Lady Sutherlands
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary and the Sanfords sail for home. Had lunch at Montefiore, tea at Broadly Road, and attended a reception at Lady Sutherlands.

entries.fullText:
Left Miss Estlns
36 Belgrave Road - Clifton
- Bristol - at 12:15 noon
- found at the C. Station the
3 lovely sisters - Mrs. Margaret
Priestman Turner & Misses May
& Anna Maria Priestman -
though the sun was boiling hot
Miss Estlne went to
station where we got on board the
London train - on reaching
Carlisle - we decided to go on to
Edinboro- a nice New York
Doctor Miss Wilson was
in our compartment - we arrived
at midnight & jwent to bed, little]
dirty quarters at the Windsor.
Where we found under my skirt at
the foot if we had - a great lot
of carpet tacks.
This was Miss Estling 79th birth
& Mrs. Gross 50th so my visit to
Miss Estlne marks her entrance upon
her 80th year - & Mrs G. upon her
51st - where too tired for anything
this [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Bristol to Edinboro, stopping at various locations and meeting with several people along the way. She notes the birthdays of Miss Estlne and Mrs. Gross.

entries.fullText:
At the Windsor Hotel
Edinboro - we took a very late
breakfast - call at Cooks
agency about our [?] tickets
then took carriage to call on Mrs.
P.B. McClaran Newbery House
She was not set up but
the daughter Dr. Agnes - Loffted
it that we were to begin
our [?] of a few days at
6 & dinner - then we drove
to the Old Castle then Mrs. Gross
look at jewelry [?] [?]
bobble - I presented her with a
heart they had one set in pearls
for her birthday present.
At half past 5 we were at
dear Mrs. McLaren - & ushered into
our cozy rooms - Alfred
Bright (son of John Bright) & wife
were there but left next P.M.
Mrs. McLaren is just as sweet
& bright as 16 years ago only
a great deal more feeble
physically.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day in Edinboro, visiting Mrs. P.B. McClaran and the Old Castle, and presenting Mrs. Gross with a birthday gift. She also notes the presence of Alfred Bright and his wife at Mrs. McLaren's.

entries.fullText:
In Edinboro - Scotland
at Mrs. Duncan McLarens
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from August 2, 1899, written in Edinboro - Scotland at Mrs. Duncan McLarens.

entries.fullText:
In Edinboro - Scotland
at Mrs. Priscilla Bright - McLarens
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from August 3, 1899, written in Edinboro - Scotland at Mrs. Priscilla Bright - McLarens.

entries.fullText: Left Edinboro at 8 A.M. & reached St. Ermins Hotel London after seven P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Edinboro to London on August 5, 1899.

entries.fullText:
Drove in Hansom - Mrs. G & B
to Richmond Hill - to
dine with dear Mrs.
Rebecca Morse - now
80 - who was our English
correspondent for The Revolution
in 1868-69 & 70 - had a very
pleasant visit & drove back
at top of the omnibus - so
had a fine top view of city
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony drove to Richmond Hill in London to dine with Mrs. Rebecca Morse, who was their English correspondent for The Revolution in 1868-69 & 70.

entries.fullText:
Left St Ermins Hotel
at 2:20 P.M. for
Basingstoke - [?]
met us - Mrs. Gross & self
at station - & after
4 o'clock tea - she
took Mrs. Gross in her carriage - & the
Little Frauline & I
were taken through
Hackward Park by a
coachman - a lovely view
of the old Beech trees & of
a large flock of baby
deer - & of the old ones in
another part of the Park -
Mrs. Gross is in Clover here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left St Ermins Hotel and went to Basingstoke where they had tea and visited Hackward Park with Mrs. Gross and Little Frauline.

entries.fullText: Harriet invited two school board women with Miss Alice Hatch - a poor Law Guardian to 4 o'clock tea on the lawn - all of the trio were very correct & intelligent in their work. All of us took a drive in the forenoon - Mr. Hatch arrived just before supper so he had a visit [?] him - Hattie & self took a long walk & had a good talk this evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Harriet, Miss Alice Hatch, Mr. Hatch, and Hattie in Basingstoke.

entries.fullText: Left Basingstoke & dear Harriet Houton Hatch - at 10 A.M. - went to St Ermins - to see friends in P.M. & pack ready to sail for home. Mrs. Harper was there full of talk of her delights of the [?] of [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Basingstoke and visits friends in St Ermins before preparing to sail home.

entries.fullText:
To sail on the
Marquette - left London
at 2:55 - wen down
on R.R. & then transferred
to ship from a tug -
a slow 2 day disagreeable
progress - formed quite
a number of persons I
knew - Mr. Laurence
who went over with us -
an actor with Southern
& who [?] in St.
Bartholomeo's Church
on Madison Avenue
N.J. the Vanderbilt
Church
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sailed on the Marquette from London to an unknown destination, describing the slow and disagreeable progress and mentioning meeting Mr. Laurence, an actor.

entries.fullText:
In the English
Channel all this
day - weather
beautiful & cold
great change from
the sultry London
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes the beautiful and cold weather in the English Channel, which is a great change from the sultry London.

entries.fullText:
Steam ship Marquettte
finally out of the
Channel
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is on the steam ship Marquette and it is finally out of the channel.

entries.fullText:
On steam ship
Marquette - Puff
Gates read English
Service at 11 A.M.,
In the evening at 9 o'clock
Rev Bamilton of
Rochester 1st M.E. Church-
read, gave out hymns & prayed
& made a few very nice
remarks & introduced me
& I tried to tell them [?]
women ought to hate-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is on the steam ship Marquette. Rev Bamilton of Rochester 1st M.E. Church read and introduced her and she spoke about women's rights.

entries.fullText: [?] - gales
entries.summaryText: [?] - gales

entries.fullText: On steamer Marquette
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was on the steamer Marquette on August 16, 1899.

entries.fullText:
On ocean steamer
Marquete - Capt Gates
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was on the ocean steamer Marquete with Capt Gates on August 17, 1899.

entries.fullText:
On steamer
Marquette - a
heavy fog with
fog horn blowing
all night long-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is on the steamer Marquette and experiences a heavy fog with fog horn blowing all night long.

entries.fullText:
On steamer ship
Marquette - a
heavy fog still &
all hoping to get
into New York
though the weather
warns us of []
heat we shall find
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is still on the steamer Marquette and experiences a heavy fog while hoping to get into New York despite the warning of heat.

entries.fullText:
Arrived - New York
3 P.M. - Mrs Gross & self went
to the St Dennis Hotel - the
Customs Officer - who took
our affidavits as to dutiable
goods in our trunks - when
he found I answered to S.B.A,
said - I ought to have known
you? & I answered & 'Who are
you'? he replied the son of
A.T. Cole - whom you used to
know & whom I have heard
talk of you a great deal' - he
was best friend n Temp. Cons in /52
- Mr. Cole took my trunk keys,
also Mrs. Gross & very soon had our
luggage in hands of Dodds Express to
for N.Y. Central Baggage room -
- the weather sultry & oppressive
- the fog prevented us from
seeing our beautiful N.Y. harbor
- We had a cheery good bye with
the very friend - from
our ten days ocean sojourn
on the Marquette - Capt. Gates
entries.summaryText: Arrival in New York, meeting with Customs Officer and A.T. Cole's son, and luggage transfer to N.Y. Central Baggage room.

entries.fullText:
At St. Dennis Hotel
all the day & weather
hot enough to melt us down
- Miss Hay & Mrs. Catt came
to lunch with us and
nephews Arthur A. &
Dr. Henry A. Baker called
in P.M. and we
took supper, then the
8 P.M. train for
Rochester - sick &
disgusted with new
York's smothering heat.
entries.summaryText: Meeting with Miss Hay, Mrs. Catt, Arthur A., and Dr. Henry A. Baker, and departure to Rochester due to the hot weather.

entries.fullText:
Reached Rochester
5.20 - & landed at
No. 17 - about 6 A.M -
and soon had one
simple breakfast -
Peaches & cream -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester on August 22, 1899 and had a simple breakfast of peaches and cream.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for August 23, 1899.

entries.fullText:
At home.
Mrs Fran taking a
genuine rest - & I
ditto - weather lovely
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs Fran are at home and taking a rest due to the lovely weather.

entries.fullText:
At home
Had Edi W. Higgins
carriage & driver & went
out East Avenue, etc.
This was our first
sally forth - we had
just lounged - & ate
& left -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and goes out for a ride with Edi W. Higgins in a carriage and driver, going out to East Avenue, on their first outing after lounging at home.

entries.fullText:
AT home
This P.M. Mr Greenley
& coachman Thomas [Man ?]
drove round & took Mrs
Fron & self Genesee Park
then across to the
reservoir & Park
a very pleasant drive
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a pleasant day at home and goes on a drive to Genesee Park, the reservoir, and Park with Mr. Greenley and Thomas.

entries.fullText:
At home
None of us went to
Church - but instead -
Mrs Gross, sister Mary & self
took electric car to Charlotte,
then to Mamton Beach -
and then back to C. Crossing
the Ferry to Somerville,
home at 3.30 - Little Annie
had waited her dinner a full
hour or a half - but her [?]
hungry enough to make it all
good -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home and goes on an electric car ride with Mrs. Gross and sister Mary to Charlotte, Mamton Beach, C. Crossing, and Somerville, returning home at 3.30pm.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Just as we got up from
breakfast - nephew Wendell [name underlined]
P. Mosher [name underlined] & son Albert came -
from Philadelphia - where they visited
niece Louise M. James -
- at 10 - we had carriage
from Mr Payne's - and
all of us drove to the old
farm home in Gates &
thence to Mt Hope -
Some 30 or more
friends called - Mrs
Fron enjoyed them
& declared them very
nice ladies -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a visit from her nephew and friends at her home in Gates and Mt Hope.

entries.fullText:
At home
Wendell & boy took
dinner with Mrs Dix
Franks wife Ella & childfren
- Mrs Gross packed
her several trunks - two
steamer - hat trunk -
steamer bundle - basket -
and one mammoth trunk -
- got them all checked om
the two tickets - she &
Wendell & their boy took
5.30 train -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's nephew and his family visit her home before leaving on a train with Mrs. Gross and her trunks.

entries.fullText:
At home
and house seemed
very still & lonely after
the week with dear
cheerful Mrs Gross -
Wrote letters &
tried catch up to go
to Stroudsburg Penn -
on the morrow
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about feeling lonely after spending time with Mrs. Gross and catching up on letters before heading to Stroudsburg Penn.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester on the
2.40 P.M. train for
Geneva & Mrs E. S. Miller's
Mrs Stanton & her maid
Anna - with John, & the new
& splendid carriage met
me at the station -
Found Nannie & Maggie
& widow & son - gone
to Fossennmen Nannies
Nannies
summer home up the
Lake - so only Mrs
Miller & myself sat at
table
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Geneva and meets with Mrs. E. S. Miller, Mrs. Stanton, and others. She finds out that Nannie, Maggie, and a widow and her son have gone to Fossennmen Nannies for the summer.

entries.fullText:
At Geneva -
with Mrs. E. S. Miller
- at 9 A.M. I drove
with "John" over to
Cousin Lucius [Hames ?]
& visited with thim &
his two girls Nettie &
Nina for two hours -
- promised to invite
Nina come & visit us
as soon as the coast
was clear -
on return
after 12 found Mrs
Stanton on the broad
piazza & Mrs Miller taking
her noon rest
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Cousin Lucius and his daughters Nettie and Nina in Geneva and promises to invite Nina to visit.

entries.fullText:
At Geneva -
Intended to go home
this evening - but decided
to stay over night [?]
at. Y. Mr Miller -, a
graduate from Michigan
State University & his bride
- Mrs Mary P. Rogers Miller
the grand daughter of
Nathaniel P. Rogers
came from Utica & she
is state lecturer for Cornell
at Cornell teachers institutes
on Nature Studies - both
are very interesting persons
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets Mr. Miller and his bride, Mrs. Mary P. Rogers Miller, who is a state lecturer for Cornell on Nature Studies and both are very interesting persons.

entries.fullText: Left Geneva on 7.05 train & reached Rochester at 9.20 - found Mary & Annie just in bed - I was soon there & heard nothing after the clock struck 10 ! Mrs Stanton & Mr & Mrs Rogers Miller drove to Station with me - A letter from brother Dr. R. Says sister Anna is & Mr & Mrs & Miss Havens were to land yesterday - & to stop a week in new job I write Sister A at St Dennis Hotel not to fail to stop & make us a visit
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Geneva to Rochester and meets with family and friends.

entries.fullText: At home Nephew Frank Mosher & wife Ella Dix - & children called - [?] took train for Philadelphia this evening - Some 20 more friends called this evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home and receives visits from family and friends.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester 6.45 A.M.
reached Elmira 10 - took Carriage
to Gleasons water cure - to see
Mrs Hamish Howland - M there &
her daughter Isabel - found her
husband & son there also - but
warm welcome from them & also
from Dr Rachel Gleason - Dr Gleason
died last spring - leaving her very lonely
with only her invalid daughter Adelle
- took lunch & drove back & took
the [12.46?] train - Lackawana for
Shandsbury - Rachel had not
received my letter - so took [?]
1 mile up the hill - found
her & three little girls - Miriam - 13.
Rose -9 - Julia 7 - all well -
after supper - began our talk
arrived at 5. P.M -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Elmira and Shandsbury, meeting with Mrs. Hamish Howland, Isabel, Dr. Rachel Gleason, and her daughter Adelle.

entries.fullText:
At Stroudsberg - Penn
Visiting & talking business with
my dear first adopted niece
Rachel Foster Avery -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Stroudsberg and meets with her first adopted niece, Rachel Foster Avery, to discuss business.

entries.fullText: Talked over work & workers - Marilyn Con a 80th Birthday - and their Rachel remained in my room until 1. Oclock A.M. talking over her personal affairs -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony talked about work and workers with Marilyn, celebrated an 80th birthday with Con, and talked about Rachel's personal affairs until 1 AM.

entries.fullText: Left Stroudsberg at 12.34 Rachel & Miriam driving me down [?] the lovely little white Sheltand Ponies Reached Rochester at 7.55 P.M. - at N.Y.P. & Weston Station - found sister Mary & little Annie not expecting me - bu I soon had lunch & went in bed before the old clock struck 9!! tired enough - but glad I had been to see Rachel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Stroudsberg with Rachel and Miriam driving her down, reached Rochester at 7:55 PM, and found sister Mary and little Annie not expecting her.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Emma [D? P ?]Sweet
called this P.M. &
spent several hours -
telling of her visit to
the Catts home the
past week - She feels
sure - as Miss Hay did when
she talked to me in New York
Station last June - that Mrs
C. will not refuse Presidency
of the National W.S.L -
Frank brings word
that Sister Anna O. went
strait through to Leavenworth
without stopping anywhere
entries.summaryText: Mrs Emma [D? P ?]Sweet visited and talked about the Catts home and Sister Anna O. went straight through to Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Spoke at noon
before Joseph Alting's
Sunday School Class - of several
hundred young men - showing
that that nonenforcement [underlined] of
good laws was the inevitable -
until there were added a new
& stronger balance of notes
to out-number that of the
men who now prevent [?]
enforcement - & that since
all men voted - there is no place
to go for the balance - but to
women - etc. & etc - spoke 40 minutes
- was very heated & tired - & yet
walked home with Sister
Mary - it seemed as if I
could not get one foot
before the other before I had
gotten half way - & that persisted
- and of this no doubt - came
the result that made its
appearance [?] P.M -
entries.summaryText: Spoke before Joseph Alting's Sunday School Class and walked home with Sister Mary.

entries.fullText: Ms. Hain called to get story about women on school board--but I refused to talk until [?] Mr Oconner, Pres of local Council- Frank Mosher & wife Ella here to tea-- & spent the evening only four called -felt sort of chilly & was a little hoarse-but thought nothing of it
entries.summaryText: Ms. Hain, Mr Oconner, Frank Mosher, and Ella visited Susan B. Anthony at her home. Ms. Hain wanted to get a story about women on the school board, but Susan refused to talk until Mr. Oconner was present. They spent the evening together and Susan felt a little hoarse.

entries.fullText: Had a hard night of it--with [threatenings?] of cold so that this morning I had no doubt left about its being one--was very hoarse--so snuggled round the fire all day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a hard night and woke up with a cold. She was very hoarse and spent the day snuggled around the fire.

entries.fullText:
At home
Cold seemed much
better slept right through
the night with very little
cough
Sister Mary called
on Mrs OConnor - 136
Frank - as she insisted
I shouldn't go out
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and feels better. Sister Mary called on Mrs. OConnor and Frank.

entries.fullText:
At home
Coughed nearly all the
night - hearing the clock
strike every time from 7 to 3 -
after that by a swallow of
water with a few drops of
camphor administered by Sister
Mary - calmed down & heard
no more until sister Mary's
heels struck the floor at 6. A.M.
In P.M. Eliza De
Garmo - & half brother
Rufus DeGarmo - called -
Uncle Elias' first wife was
a Powell - & had eight children
- , second wife Rhoda Rogers
had two - Eliza & Robert - Prof.
De Garmo of Cornell University is
son of Rufus - so a grand-
son of Elias De Garmo -
Am expecting Mrs J. O. Coma
to schools committee nominations
Mrs Oconnor's talk seemed fair
& as if she were awake to the
duties of the Pres. of Local Council
representing 24 of the city Societies
of women
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and had trouble sleeping due to coughing. Eliza De Garmo and Rufus DeGarmo visited and they discussed family history. Susan is expecting Mrs. J. O. Coma for school committee nominations. Mrs. Oconnor's talk seemed fair and she appeared to be aware of the duties of the President of Local Council representing 24 of the city Societies of women.

entries.fullText: Nursing the cold - out of patience - I begged Sister Mary to go & telephone Dr Ruker to call - She did so - & gave me two medicines & I plied them alternating each hour religiously - & by night I felt a decided lighting up of the pressure & irritation of the bronchials & managed not to cough on going to bed -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is nursing a cold and begged Sister Mary to call Dr Ruker. She took two medicines and felt better by night.

entries.fullText: Dr Sherman Rucker came cold better - but gave me still another set of curatives - the dry weather & the air filled with dust is very irritating - - This A.M. a telegram from Rev Anna H. Shaw - saying arrived all well - pleasant voyage - they are the last - except Mrs Harper of our Summer Voyagers over the [???????] in London - She and Lucy will find welcome home letters at 1630 Diamond St Phila - Mary McLean Maxwell - Aunt [Soffia?] [?] [?] [?] N. McLean's only daughter called - of [Dalan??] - Nephew Frank & wife Ella - to say good Bye - he returns to his home - Sioux City Iowa - leaving wife & their children with mother in Law - Mrs Sarah Dix -
entries.summaryText: Dr Sherman Rucker came and gave Susan B. Anthony another set of curatives. She received a telegram from Rev Anna H. Shaw and Mary McLean Maxwell visited her. Nephew Frank and his wife Ella also visited to say goodbye before returning to Sioux City, Iowa.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Sister Mary went
to Church - also to
hear Mrs Poole - Temperance
lecture in P.M. - but I
decided to keep inside
another day - the heat & dryness
are something oppressive -
- Had long talk with little
Annie Dann - about her
future - whether house - work -
as two years past - Trained
nursing - or stenographer & type
writing -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony talks about staying at home due to the oppressive heat and having a long talk with Annie Dann about her future.

entries.fullText:
at Home -
After dinner - sallied
forth to Security
Trust Bank - got
$500 - draft check to
general Treasury National
to pay of the clerks of the
Treas. Com. Sec. & Head quarters -
- just learned that not one
had been paid since
last May - each having
borrowed money to live on
- it is a [?] shame -
that not an officer - during my
absence came to their rescue!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to the Security Trust Bank to get a $500 draft check to pay off the clerks of the Treasury Commission Secretary and Headquarters who have not been paid since last May.

entries.fullText:
At HOme - [underlined]
It is 35 years ago to day
that dear niece Ann Eliza
McLean - was buried - it
was then - [?] Sept. 19. 1864 -
and what a heart break that
was to sister Guelma & her
husband - Aaron M McLean - A.E.
was their first born - lucky but
a few days of being 24 years old -
- It was the 25th anniversary day
of their marriage -

At last rain has come
- Hope it may last & prove
to be a good equinoxal week -

Spent the day trying
to write a letter to Mrs J.A. McLean
Washington D.C. - in reply to her
appeal for me to call out my
'Suffrage Girls' in Ohio to work
for the election of her husband
for Governor - he is nominated
on the Democratic ticket
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the anniversary of her niece's death, the rain, and her efforts to write a letter to Mrs. J.A. McLean in Washington D.C. regarding her appeal for Susan to call out her 'Suffrage Girls' in Ohio to work for the election of her husband for Governor.

entries.fullText:
At home
Set about work trying
to finish letter to Mrs
J. R. McLean - but
the mountain labored
& brot forth only the
proverbial mouse -
Mrs Sweet came at
4 P.M. & took several
letters -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her attempts to finish a letter to Mrs. J.R. McLean and Mrs. Sweet's visit to take several letters.

entries.fullText:
At home
Worked all the forenoon
getting my letter to Mrs John
R.M. McLean - Washington D.C.
half-way to my mind -
after dinner took it to Mrs
Sweet to copy - Mrs Haire found
by telephone - that Mrs Montgomery
was at Mrs Wm. Eastwoods - 3 Argyle
st - so I went with her - & talked
over School Board Mrs Montgomery
seems to be the woman upon [?]
all the men think the right
one for that place - she will
stand if nominated. Mrs Sweet called with
copy. On return home found Mrs
Blackall, Mrs D.M. Anthony
& Mrs Burgess - the latters daughter
works in telephone office nights -
Had telephone put into Sister
Marys office room - below stairs -
first message came from Mrs
Haires. Mrs Brazer came
in evening - talked over winters
P.E. Club program with Sister
Mary who really has to carry
the whole work on her head & heart -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony discusses her letter to Mrs. John R.M. McLean, talks about the School Board, and discusses the P.E. Club program with Sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
At Home
called on Mrs O'Connor
146 Frank st - near Jay st - to
talk over - women nominees
for School Board - also
meeting of Local Council to unite
all in inviting or offering to give
a reception to the State Federation of
Clubs to meet in this city - Tuesday
Wed. Thurs. Frid. Nov 7.8.9.10 - she
is Pres. of Council & will call a
meeting for the purpose-
Then called on Mayor Warner
to women & School Board -
he was very suave - but had
his man study the constitution
to learn if women are eligible!!
Then called on Ex. Mayor
Aldridge - the Repub. boss. &
he was out -
I used to think this niece
Susie R.'s birth day - but it was instead
Sept. 21. 1872 - so she would have been
- is - 27 years old to day - what
a splendid woman she would
have been - just in her prime -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony discusses women nominees for School Board, a meeting of Local Council, and her visit to Mayor Warner and Ex. Mayor Aldridge.

entries.fullText:
At home
Dem & Chron. splendid on the
Women's Iligibility to School
Board --
Letter from Miss Shaw she &
Niece Lucy left Phila. yesterday for
Wianno - Cape - Cod cottage to
shut it up for the winter --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a newspaper article on women's eligibility to school board, a letter from Miss Shaw and her niece Lucy leaving Phila. for Wianno - Cape - Cod cottage.

entries.dateText: Wea. rainy day Sun. Sept. 24, 1899 Ther.
entries.fullText:
At home
Sister Mary, Self & Annie
E. Dann -- went to hear Mr Gannett
Some call it Evolution others
call it God -- It was a clear
splendid setting forth that all
is God -- Charles Mann
telephoned me -- when I was
up stairs for a sleep -- he has
a return of the heart trouble
of a year ago --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a lecture by Mr. Gannett and receiving a phone call from Charles Mann about his heart trouble.

entries.fullText:
C. C. Catt at Baltimore - Friends
Meeting House - Park Avenue & Lawrence St -
& tomorrow C.C.C. speaks for the Md
State W.C.J.M. at Baltimore
[State ?]
Mary had Miss Imogene Dewey,
" Miss Frank Riechenbach to tea -
to talk over P.E. Club Program
for the winter - Mrs Helen A.
also in with Mrs Blackall & Mrs
Charlotte Wilbur [Griffing ?] called -
- -
They brought word of the
death of Judge George F. Danforth
this A.M. in the Court room
at 11 Oclock - just after he
had made a clean - out
argument before Judge Werner
he was 80 years old - he
has been a good driend of
suffrage for women - and
one of the pioneers of the
Unitarian Church since 1840 -
Anna [Darma ?] began school of
stenography & type [?] to [?]
entries.summaryText: C. C. Catt speaks at the Md State W.C.J.M. in Baltimore. Susan B. Anthony receives news of the death of Judge George F. Danforth, a friend of suffrage for women and one of the pioneers of the Unitarian Church since 1840.

entries.fullText:
Rained all the day -
- heard nothing from
the family of Judge George
F. Danforth - except through
the papers - he leave two daughters
Mrs Miller - New York - & Mrs
Huntington of this city - and
one son - Hary Danforth
all the papers. the members of
the bar speak in highest terms
of him - he was 80. July 4 / 99 -
so but a few months older than I.
we all thought not over 70 -

Dear Admiral Dewey
with his Flag Ship - Olympia
arrived N.Y. Harbor this A.M.
two days before he was expected -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives news of the death of Judge George F. Danforth and mentions the family he leaves behind. Admiral Dewey arrives in New York Harbor earlier than expected.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at home
Sister Mary went to
Charlotte to dine with
Mrs Greenleaf - who is
spending this & next month
at their farm house on
the Lake shore -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary went to Charlotte to dine with Mrs Greenleaf who is spending this & next month at their farm house on the Lake shore.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at Home - [underlined]

Rev. A. H Shaw speaks for the
Maine State W.B.J.W.
Portland [underlined]

Funeral of Judge
George F. Danforth - at
3 P.M. - Mr Garmet read the
[?] Chapel Burial Service
entries.summaryText: Rev. A. H Shaw speaks for the Maine State W.B.J.W. Funeral of Judge George F. Danforth at 3 P.M.

entries.fullText:
At Home

Miss Shaw at Phenix R. Island
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw is at Phenix R. Island.

entries.fullText:
At home
This is the 16th birthday of Hattie Nortons - Nora [underlined] also the first anniversary of nephew D.R. A's little baby Eleanor Havens Anthony -
entries.summaryText: It is Hattie Nortons' 16th birthday and the first anniversary of D.R. A's baby Eleanor Havens Anthony.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self went
to Church -- Mr Gannet spoke
on the kind of Man I'd
like my boy to be' -- fortunately
he wound up by saying -- &
his girl he would like to
be possessed of precisely the
same characteristics when
she becomes a woman --
Lucky for his girl -- that
she doesn't have to be made
over into something becoming her
sex --
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Sister Mary and listened to Mr. Gannet's speech about the kind of man she would like her son to be.

entries.fullText:
The Ohio state W. S. A's
Annual Con. at Akron -
this day & tomorrow - had to
decline invitation made by its
[express request of dear old
friend Rev Olympia Brown]
Pres - Harriet Stanton (Brown)
but wrote letter to be read --
Mrs C. C. Catt and Miss Hay there —

Purchased a Smith
Premier type writing machine --
$100 + $25 - to be paid to National
Treasury for adverting machine in our
little Bulletin -- a type
writer - Miss Fox came - do
I now begin much in good
earnest -- got off quite a
number of letters -- and dictatednough to keep the girl busy while
I am gone to the annual meeting in
the morning --
Mrs Sackett, Mrs
H. B. Clark, Mrs Blackall, & Mrs
Rupert -- at tea -- the only other
caller was Miss Williams the music
teacher.
entries.summaryText: Missed the Ohio state W. S. A's Annual Con. at Akron due to an invitation decline, but wrote a letter to be read. Purchased a Smith Premier type writing machine and got off quite a number of letters. Had tea with Mrs. Sackett, Mrs. H. B. Clark, Mrs. Blackall, Mrs. Rupert, and Miss Williams the music teacher.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Local formal meeting - Watson House -
at 10-20 - nearly all of the 34 [?] [?]
& members of Ex. Grn. present -
- no person - woman to offer
Political parties to nominate softer
upon - Mrs Montgomery drew
back - where it came to the forms
of allowing her name to be presented -
- how she vascillates - & - the
Riesehling has absolutely withdrawn
her name - The enemy note
Lay just like women!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a local formal meeting at Watson House where nearly all of the 34 members of Ex. Grn. were present. Mrs. Montgomery drew back when it came to the forms of allowing her name to be presented and Riesehling has absolutely withdrawn her name.

entries.fullText:
Miss Frank Beichenbach's new
school (No. 1) house to be
dedicated this eveg - 8 O clock -
& S. A. A. promised to speak
on the occasion - a carriage to call
for Ine - The
eveg was fine - & &
splendid andrenir
in a new & beautiful
building -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the dedication of Miss Frank Beichenbach's new school house and S. A. A. speaking on the occasion.

entries.fullText:
At Home - Mrs Fox came 4.20 - gae her dictations until 7.45 - Went Watson House to Council - Mrs Montgomery had [?] to let her name start for school board - the rank & file cannot [?] with the Pes. & two or more others a sort of lazy [?] meeting -

Miss Shaw at Boston - Mass - [W.C.I.H. ?]

Home to dinner at 1 - and at 2.30 - to P.E. [?] first meeting - Sister Mary presided well & everybody seemed pleased with her - after supper - I went over the type written letters, signed my name, & wrote one {//} & took 17 to mail box at 9.30 P.M. - making a pretty big days work
Got letter from nephew Wendell News filled me with apprehension but [?] sympathy for his brother such as the [?] for his [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day at home, a council meeting, a P.E. meeting, and receiving a letter from her nephew.

entries.fullText: At home - and working away trying to clear up my desk & begin at the bushels full of letters to answer & books to acknowledge
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about working from home and trying to clear up her desk.

entries.fullText:
At home
Had Nellie Fox copy my five
page letter to nephew Wendell
on type-writer relative to Franks
their lack of [Wismer's?] integrity -!

At eve'g called at Dem.
office & went to Mrs.
Bigelows with Mrs Hair -
found the Council Com.
had met -- a had called
on both Dem. & Republican leaders
about nominating Mrs. Montgomery
their feeling was quite hopeful

Mrs Catt & Miss Hay in
Chicago Thursday - before the
P. E. [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a letter she had Nellie Fox copy for her nephew Wendell, her visit to Mrs. Bigelows, and the Council Com. meeting. She also mentions Mrs. Montgomery's nomination and Mrs. Catt and Miss Hay's visit to Chicago.

entries.dateText: Wea. warm & raining at night Sun. Oct. 8, 1899 Ther.
entries.fullText:
At home - went to Church
Mr. G's subject 'Is religion on
the decline' - answer 'no' but
throwing off non-essential theologies &
taking on a deeper spiritual living
Miss Shaw at - Philadelphia
[?] sermon for W.C.T.U
& going to Somerton to see
Rachel in P.M.
Wrote a hurried line to
nephew Wendell - after reading
his letter of the 1st from Chicago -
telling of his promise to put his
name to notes from his brother
Frank to insurance companies

Sister Mary, Anna E. Dann
& sister Jennie & friend Mabel
with Sister May went to Lake
Avenue Baptist to hear a Baptist
Missionary tell her story of [?]
in Salt Lake & Utah -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending church and Miss Shaw's sermon for W.C.T.U. She also mentions writing a letter to her nephew Wendell and her sisters' visit to Lake Avenue Baptist to hear a Baptist Missionary's story about Salt Lake and Utah.

entries.fullText:
Kansas State Convention -
at Kansas City - sent
letter - setting forth duty
of women to make of
themselves a balance of
power for best men &
best measures - regardless
of party politics
entries.summaryText: Attended Kansas State Convention in Kansas City and sent a letter emphasizing the duty of women to make themselves a balance of power for the best men and measures, regardless of party politics.

entries.fullText:
Wyoming County - P.W. [Chits?]
annual meeting at
Castile - Mrs Grossett
Pres - Mrs Pierce at
Castile the manager -
entries.summaryText: Attended the annual meeting of the Wyoming County P.W. [Chits?] in Castile, where Mrs. Grossett was the President and Mrs. Pierce was the manager.

entries.fullText:
The Iowa State Con - at
Mason City - sent
letter urging continuation
of good organization work
until Amendment was carried
through the Legislature of 1900 -
& the Legislation & at the
ballot box in 1902!!
Democratic City Con. to nominate
all officers -
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from the Iowa State Con urging continuation of good organization work until Amendment was carried through the Legislature of 1900 and the Legislation and at the ballot box in 1902. Democratic City Con to nominate all officers.

entries.fullText:
Iowa State W.S. A.
annual meeting at Mason City -
Miss Shaw & Mrs Catt to be
there - & I trust my letter also''


Republican City Con.
to nominate officers
entries.summaryText: Attended the Iowa State W.S. A. annual meeting at Mason City with Miss Shaw and Mrs Catt. Republican City Con to nominate officers.

entries.fullText: Monroe County Annual meeting - of P.E. Association - at Churchville - Mrs. Stebbins - Good Government Club meeting also Prohibition Party meeting - Miss Shaw - Morrison - Ill.
entries.summaryText: Attended Monroe County Annual meeting and Good Government Club meeting in Churchville. Also attended Prohibition Party meeting in Morrison, Illinois with Miss Shaw.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText:
At Home - the
Political Equality Club's
first reception with us
no. 17 Madison N -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the Political Equality Club's first reception at her home in Madison N.
Susan B. Anthony did not write an entry on this day.

entries.fullText:
At home
Went Dr Regina's had both
eye teeth re-fitted - the under
wisdom took pretty dubious -

Rev & Mrs Garnett to tea -

Miss Shaw arrived at 8. P.M,
the first we have seen
her since return from
Europe - she came from
Michigan
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her dental appointment, having guests over for tea, and Miss Shaw's arrival from Michigan.

entries.fullText:
Niece Suzy [E. ?] arrived
this A.M. - glad
to have her with us -
[Next paragraph is circled]
Suzy, Mary & self
went to Church - where
she met [?] A;exander
George Smith et al -
This for [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her niece's arrival and going to church with her niece and Mary where they met A;exander George Smith and others.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw remained
at home is trying to
work up her new
lecture promised on
the White Man's Burden
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw stayed at home and worked on her new lecture.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw left 9. A.M,
for Bradford Pa - She
gave her pass
down & back - had
quite a large number
of calls, among them
Anna O's friend Mr Bacon
to see niece Suzy E.
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw left for Bradford and had a busy day with many calls, including one from Anna O's friend Mr Bacon to see Suzy E.

entries.fullText:
at home
Miss Shaw returned
at noon - & set
about her study
on new lecture
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw returned home and worked on a new lecture.

entries.fullText:
[N.Y. ? N.J. ?] State Woman Suffrage
association 31st annual meeting
in Dunkirk - Mrs
Elnora M. Babcock - manager -
guest of Mr & Mrs
[?] - Three daughters
one son & one grand
daughter - the family
a large reception
this evening in parlors
of Woman's Union -
Miss Shaw remained
at home - while Sister
Mary [?] went to Dunkirk
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Elnora M. Babcock, the manager of the State Woman Suffrage association, attended the 31st annual meeting in Dunkirk. Miss Shaw stayed home while Sister Mary [?] went to Dunkirk. Mr. & Mrs. [?] hosted a large reception for Mrs. Babcock and her family.

entries.fullText:
[first paragraph crossed out - written over it Woman Suffrage]

Good audience in
women's Union Hall -
A.M. & P.M. - Miss Shaw
came at evening
when meeting was in
Academy Hall - a
beautiful audience room
in their High School
a packed audience -
Mrs Blake & the [may ?] spoke
before me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at a meeting in Union Hall and Academy Hall with Miss Shaw and Mrs Blake in attendance.

entries.fullText:
[?] State W.S.A.
at Deunkirk -
meeting again in A.M. & P.M.
& Miss Shaw main
evening speaker - Mrs
Howell & Mr Williams
preceded her - It was
a hard rain - so
audience was not
so large still good -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting in Deunkirk with Miss Shaw, Mrs Howell, and Mr Williams as speakers despite the rain.

entries.fullText:
Left Dunkirk &
at Buffalo found
ticket not good on
Empire State train
so paid Miss Shaw for my fare
& we reached
home at 2 P.M. -
Miss Shaw had mileage back
& I bound not to let her
get too much ahead of me.
Gave her my half-doz. pocket
handerchiefs bought in New
York Aug 21st for 25 cts apiece -
after landing from cheap London
- & they really are as nice
Sister May & dear
Emily Howland came
at 8.30 - they waited at B,
to come on their reduced
rate tickets
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Dunkirk to Buffalo with Miss Shaw, gives her a gift, and is joined by Sister May and Emily Howland.

entries.fullText:
At home
Miss Howland, Lucy E [?]
May & self went to Church -
Mr H very much liked
Mr. Garnnett - after
dinner Sister May &
Miss H called at
Mrs. Greenleafs
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home with Miss Howland, Lucy E, and Sister May, attends church, and visits Mrs. Greenleafs with Sister May and Miss H.

entries.fullText:
Miss Howland left
for home - Sherwood -
this A.M.-
entries.summaryText: Miss Howland left for home in Sherwood.

entries.fullText:
Election Day
Resulted in favor of Republican ticket
Mayor Carnahan & Mrs Helen
Barrett Montgomery for School board
N.Y. State Federation of Clubs
Rochester N.Y. S.B.A. Chairman
of political studies - one half hour
five minutes speeches - no one of them
to say woman suffrage!! To talk of
studying politics but not a word of
[?] kind or substance matter -
- some 300 or 350 delegates
arrived - was a platform
- Mrs Helmuth gave me
hearty greeting -
at evening - after hearing that
Mrs Montgomery was elected
dressed - Miss Shaw, Miss Mills
Sister Mary & niece Lucy E & all
went to Po[????] Hotel to their
informal reception and there
was great rejoicing
entries.summaryText: Election Day resulted in favor of Republican ticket. Attended N.Y. State Federation of Clubs in Rochester, where there was no mention of woman suffrage. Attended Mrs Montgomery's reception in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Federation of Clubs
Attended A.M. & P.M. lesson
& Lunched at Watson
[?] with Officers & [?]
[word crossed out] Women's E [?] [?] Union
the hostess - everything was
very nice - Mrs Wm [Hoyt?]
master of ceremonies.
None of us went to the
Musical this evening -
entries.summaryText: Attended Federation of Clubs and lunched at Watson with Officers and Women's E Union.

entries.fullText:
Attend the morning session
of Federation of Clubs -
Lunched with Mrs[?] Outhout
Last Avenue - Miss Shaw
Mrs Helmut [?] - and had
to Eureka Hall for evening
Political Study hour - 3.30
the speakers of which were
5 [number circled] Rev Anna Howes Shaw -
Evolution of Citizenship
Responsibilities of women as citizens
3 [number circled] Fannie Humphrey Gaffney
41 - Riverside Drive - New York City
2 [number circled] Mrs Blake - needed Legislation for
the women of the [?]
4 [number circled] Helen Barnett Montgomery
[two words crossed out] Political Study
for Mothers & Teachers -
This was [?] the livest &
best hour of the 8 session
The small reception in the
evening at Eureka Hall
entries.summaryText: Attended morning session of Federation of Clubs, had lunch with Mrs Outhout, Miss Shaw, and Mrs Helmut, and attended evening Political Study hour at Eureka Hall.

entries.fullText:
Federation of Clubs
again attended both
sessions & at very close
- when a resolution not to
allow the seating of Brigham
H. Roberts of Utah - I
threw in my word - by request of
the Pres. Mr Helmuth -
against one women's protesting
against seating a Mormon
who had violated the law
of monogamy - while never
raising a protest against the
seating in Congress or any other
high position - Christian men
known to the violators of
that law. & all other laws for
the protection of girls & weak or
wicked women outside
of Utah
100 or more called this eve'g -
Miss Shaw left this A.M. to speak
in Bath -
Niece Lucy E. (?) with
Hattie Richmond Hell - + spent
eve'g + took supper at Charles
Mann's - he was very ill then
entries.summaryText: Attended the Federation of Clubs, spoke against seating Brigham H. Roberts of Utah, and spent the evening with Miss Shaw, Lucy E., Hattie Richmond Hell, and Charles Mann.

entries.fullText:
- at home
Niece Lucy E. still
with us - feeling sad over
her visit at Charles Mann's -
he was so miserable &
yet put forth every effort to
seem like his old self -
entries.summaryText: At home with Lucy E. who is feeling sad over her visit to Charles Mann's, where he was miserable but tried to seem like his old self.

entries.fullText:
Neice Lucy took the 9.30 A.M. train for Phila. it was cold icy & raining – so we let her go alone to the Lehigh Station – was provoked at myself that I didn’t in spite of her protests, call a carriage–
The papers coming down on me for opposing the Anti-Roberts resolution in the Federation of clubs on this P.M. the 10th it always hurts to suggest plucking the [?] out, of our own eye, before taking the [?] from our neighbors– Did not go to church-
entries.summaryText: Susan's niece Lucy left for Phila and Susan is upset she didn't call a carriage. Susan is being criticized for opposing the Anti-Roberts resolution in the Federation of clubs.

entries.fullText: [?] [?] called this evening — [?] – the Ballowell, Willis & Joseph [?]– daughter [?] [P??] – Willis – wife of Edmund & Willis brother Samuel – of weathering Long Island – she came up to the federation-
entries.summaryText: Unknown people visited Susan's home, including someone from Long Island who came for the federation.

entries.fullText:
Dined at Sarah C. Willis' - Holland
& Bolins - Catherine Post Willis & daughter
P.E. Club at Brighton &
S.B..A. promised to speak
a large audience in Brighton
Hall- full half from Rochester
a pleasant evening

Wea. Fri Nov 17, 1899 Ther
Went to Dr Regna's this
A.M. he filled right-eye tooth -
9 A.M. and I paid him
$3. - which he said made us even
- I just do not know
what to decide - both eye teeth
are lame - & yet
may last me to the end -
the fear of a new plate's
interfering with my up
to this time distinct enunciation - prevents me
from saying the word for a
new me -
Darwin Mann telephoned
this forenoon
that Charles Mann was
very bad - Dr. said not
likely to live - Sister May
went over- at once
entries.summaryText: Dined at Sarah C. Willis' - Holland & Bolins - Catherine Post Willis & daughter P.E. Club at Brighton & S.B..A. promised to speak a large audience in Brighton Hall- full half from Rochester a pleasant evening. Went to Dr Regna's this A.M. he filled right-eye tooth - 9 A.M. and I paid him $3. - which he said made us even - I just do not know what to decide - both eye teeth are lame - & yet may last me to the end - the fear of a new plate's interfering with my up to this time distinct enunciation - prevents me from saying the word for a new me - Darwin Mann telephoned this forenoon that Charles Mann was very bad - Dr. said not likely to live - Sister May went over- at once

entries.fullText:
at home
Spent - most - of
The afternoon at
Charles Mann's -
- he was easier - &
sleeping some - but
Dr had forbidden any
one to see him -
on returning I went in
to see Dr Mulligan
- & he said he might go
any minute - and might
live weeks or months yet
so I decided not to telegraph
his father - who is in St
Louis - & to preach there
tomorrow - then to [Hand?]
for [Nocher?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the afternoon at Charles Mann's and visited Dr Mulligan who said that Charles might go any minute or live weeks or months yet. She decided not to telegraph Charles' father who is in St Louis.

entries.fullText:
May & day went to
Church - & after it - I
went to M Sarmetto to
dinner - her sister & husband
Burnham - were there -
George Smith went to
Charles Manns - & telegraph
he was just gone - at
3 P.M. all was over -

They got no telegram from
his father - but hoped he
was on his way here -

It proved that he did
not get the our telly' of,
his death - before leaving
So didn't know of it till
he reached [?] house
[?ng] night - 10 O clock
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to church and then to M Sarmetto's for dinner where Burnham was present. George Smith went to Charles Mann's and telegraphed that Charles was just gone. Charles' father did not receive the telegram and did not know of Charles' death until he reached his house at 10 o'clock at night.

entries.fullText: Speak for the Women's Wednesday Club - of the Brick Church - [?] short - 'How Women can Help' at 3.30 - P.M. Mrs. Dr Collins will send carriage at 2.15.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony will speak at the Women's Wednesday Club at the Brick Church on 'How Women can Help'. Mrs. Dr Collins will send a carriage at 2.15.

entries.fullText: Wea. Sun. Nov. 26, 1899 Ther.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated November 26, 1899.

entries.fullText:
Wea. Mon. Nov.27, 1899 Ther.
Irondequoit Chapter
Daughters American Revolution
meet Mrs. Alfred Gould Wrights
506- West Avenue- at 3.30
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated November 27, 1899, mentioning a meeting of the Irondequoit Chapter of the Daughters American Revolution at Mrs. Alfred Gould Wrights' residence on 506 West Avenue at 3:30 PM.

entries.fullText: Sarah Eliza Hyatt- the only daughter of Elijah, Bandau Hyatt of Battemville died this evening- Edgar P. who live with her in the old home -(the Semi green house) wrote the letter- The only old friend and neighbor now left in Battemville is Abigail Fitch M Dean & her only son Fitch- the widow of John C M Dean- Son of Uncle Jonny M Dean
entries.summaryText: Sarah Eliza Hyatt, the only daughter of Elijah and Bandau Hyatt of Battemville, has died. Edgar P. wrote the letter. The only old friend and neighbor now left in Battemville is Abigail Fitch M Dean and her only son Fitch, the widow of John C M Dean, son of Uncle Jonny M Dean.

entries.fullText:
National A.W.S.A. Conference
Indianapolis, Ind.
Mrs. Grace Julian Clarke
158 S. Central [] Irvington - Ind
Pierce-
Guest of Mrs Wright-Jewell
633 [???]
entries.summaryText: Attended National A.W.S.A. Conference in Indianapolis, staying with Mrs. Grace Julian Clarke and as a guest of Mrs Wright-Jewell.

entries.fullText: Spent entire day at the Dennison Hotel in Business Com. Meetings - Mrs Catt, Mrs [?], Mrs [Clay?], Mrs M'Cullough & self- The [C??] women formed a club & elected their officers Mrs Ketcham President
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at the Dennison Hotel in Indianapolis attending business committee meetings with Mrs Catt, Mrs [?], Mrs [Clay?], and Mrs M'Cullough. The women formed a club and elected Mrs Ketcham as President.

entries.fullText:
At M.W. Sewalls. Ind [?]
at nearly noon - Mrs Clay, Mrs
Cullough & Mrs Upton called &
gave me inner views of
Miss Hay's ambition to be [?]
O. in C.C.C.'s place - - all
agreed it couldn't be gratified
if best interests of [?] prevailed -
Mrs Julian Clarke
called - & at evening Mrs
Pierce came to tea -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Clay, Mrs Cullough & Mrs Upton called & gave me inner views of Miss Hay's ambition to be O. in C.C.C.'s place.

entries.fullText:
Left Indianapolis at .7 last evening
& reach Detroit at 6.50 - this
A.M. took carriage to
79 Winder St - Cousin Benj.
M. Anthony's - in time for
breakfast with Cousin Elizabeth
after dinner we went to
Mrs , sisiter of Mrs
Helen Phillis Jenkins to
Women's Club - talked to them
First both children, home
A.McGraw, & Howard M.
came to dinner at 79 -
then Howard accompanied
his mother & me to [?]
Hall to look upon the [?]
Federation of Labor - after that
to the Women's Club - & after
that to Mrs McGrasw to dinner
at 9 evening the rain poured
- but they got a carriage &
we sped home dry - but
it was a rainy sloppy day
altogether -
entries.summaryText: Arrived in Detroit and had breakfast with Cousin Elizabeth. Attended Women's Club and Federation of Labor. Had dinner with A.McGraw, Howard M., and Mrs McGrasw.

entries.fullText:
American Federation of Labor
Detroit - Mich -
At cousin B. M. Anthony's
79 -Winder street - storming-
Cousin E. got carriage & took me
to Harmonie Hall - no to Gibson Hotel
to see Secretary Morrison & [?]
Pres. Duncan - both promised
to get petition before the committee
& to notify us when I could
address them - then we
drove around - & on return
to house - a carriage was
waiting to take me to Mrs
Huttons - to Per Gradus club -
of which Mrs Howard M.
Anthony is Pres - then I spoke
for 20 or 22 minutes - then
home to dinner & was all
undressed for a nap when letter came
that I should speak at Labor Con -
at once - & I went - & from there cousin
E & I went to Winston Church fair
& supper. met very good friends- among
them ex senator T. W. Palmer who
invited Miss Bates & me to lunch
with him -

[*Took 6 Olock dinner with cousin
Howard M. Anthony & wife this eveg*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels around Detroit, Michigan, visiting the American Federation of Labor, Harmonie Hall, Gibson Hotel, Mrs. Hutton's Per Gradus club, and the Winston Church fair. She meets with various people, including ex-senator T. W. Palmer, and is invited to lunch with him.

entries.fullText:
Detroit - Mich
Cousin E. had carriage
& took me 1st Hayes
photographer - where he took
general pictures - then
to Spencer's Business
College - Wilcox St -
to talk 40 minutes - at 10
Miss Octavia Williams Bates
& self took electric car to
six miles point - where ex
Senator Palmer's man met
us with carriage & drove us
to splendid house - farm
house he calls it - but there
was no Mrs P. to meet us -
she lives in her own elegant
home at Larchmont east of
New Rochelle, N.Y. her
staid to Lunch - senator wrote
letter to President McKinley to
appoint Mrs Potter Palmer one of the
12 Paris Exposition Commissioners - I slipped
on polished floor - broke gold glasses
& loaned the senators to go home with
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Hayes photographer and Spencer's Business College in Detroit, Michigan. She then travels to six miles point with Octavia Williams Bates to visit ex-Senator Palmer's farm house. She slips and breaks her glasses.

entries.fullText:
Left Detroit at -9.50 A.M,
-breakfast at 7.30- wrote reso-
lution for American Federation of
Labor Convention - left it with
cousin Elizabeth - to give to
Mr Max Morris of Denver
to present - cousin E. took
me in carriage to the station
- was alone in sleeper
until Buffalo - had a
dozy day of it - reached Rochester
at 8.40 - was home & in
bed when clock struck ten -
sister Mary had kept lamp
burning & one eye open for me
last night until twelve -
All well - & was glad
enough to get into my
own bed once more -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Detroit to Rochester, stopping in Buffalo, and spends the day alone in a sleeper.

entries.fullText:
At home - up &
breakfast at 7.30 - and at
work on huge pile of letters-
spent day with Miss Hawley
adding to or taking from article
for N.J. World's Centennial Calendar
Mrs Dix called - very curious
about Wendells contract with [?]
- went to Mrs Ezra R. Andrews
Exchange St - to College Women's
Club to listen to Prof. Barnes
on history of English schools
more particularly since the Household
Suffrage Law - 1867 - which
he however did not mention.
- his wife was daughter of Principal
Sheldon of Oswego Normal School
died in London a year ago -
he spoke of her cooperating in
studies with him - Miss
Ollie Ramis is President
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home working on letters and meeting with Miss Hawley. She also attends a lecture by Prof. Barnes on the history of English schools.

entries.fullText: Hardly made a beginning on pile of letters accumulated during my 11 days absence - But did get a letter to Sunday World's Centennial - Mr Hirsch - of Status of Women close of 29th century & hope for the 20th century. Miss Hawley very good & patient.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her pile of letters and sending a letter to Sunday World's Centennial regarding the status of women.

entries.fullText: Mr. Gannetts sister Mrs Kate Gannett Wells preached for us - Duty of 19th Century Women to Twentieth Century women - She remembered to forget to give the climax of all our legacies - that of universal desire for a voice in making & enforcing the laws - she recounted 9 legacies all very well - but as nothing without the ballot - for the twentieth - more than they have been [?] it to us of the 19th.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. Kate Gannett Wells preaching about the duty of 19th century women to 20th century women and the importance of the ballot.

entries.fullText:
At home -
Mrs Maria Wilder
Dupuy - sister of Sam'l &
Webster Wilder - was at
supper with us & spent
eveg- no one called - except
at 9:20 - Minnie Sackett Smith
with great niece Guelma
McLean Baker - came - full
of glee - both of them -
Guelma came from Toronto
Thursday - Modgeska - with
whom Gula is - had been
playing - for a week in Toronto -
- she is full of certainty
that best of success awaits
her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the evening at home with Mrs. Maria Wilder, Dupuy, Minnie Sackett Smith, and Guelma McLean Baker. They discuss Modgeska's success in Toronto.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester at 9. A.M.
on Pittsburg R.R. and reached
Butler at 5:20 P.M. - and
went to Willard Hotel -
- it was very full - but
finally Mr Raurer of the
R. & P. Rail Road gave up his
room to me - & he camped in
some smaller place - it
is a pleasant enough room
- but oh the smell of the
creosote - everything full of it -
and when I pulled the
blankets about my neck it was
fairly suffocating - such is the
habit of tobacco smoking!
- Rev McArthur -
Baptist Minister of N.Y. city- that
cousin Fanny Benson works so [???b] of
lectured on Russia - had full
house - gave lots of information
- but his mannerisms detracted
from his address - he gave S.B.P.
a high [fluff?] - comparing her to Queen
Victoria &c - I did not go to
speak to him - but sped me to hotel
& into bed as soon as possible -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Butler and stays at the Willard Hotel. She attends a lecture on Russia by Rev McArthur and is compared to Queen Victoria.

entries.fullText:
Lecture for Miss Shaw - $40.
Prof. Howard Painter -
County Sup't. Butler Co. Public Schools-
at Willard Hotel - Mrs Heiring-owner & manager.
her husband got rich in oil - died & left her a $60.000-insurance -
with which she purchased this fine hotel building. She has 3 children-
& is giving them good educational advantages - a large number of Butler Co. teachers
in the Hotel - in all in attendance at the Institute - now are about 400 - every teacher who fails to be at roll call every morning at noon is [?] & has her salary docked - So every teacher in the county must attend every day of the [?] [?] -& lose his or her salary. Looked in upon them in the Court House a few minutes - Had splendid audience spoke 1 1/2 hour - all sat quietly & seemed earnestly listening - sup't Twithead -[?] Bethlehem-introduced me-gave moral [?] plus Political Power
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture for Miss Shaw and visited the Willard Hotel in Butler County, Pennsylvania. She also spoke at the Court House and met with teachers.

entries.fullText:
At 9.30 went to Court House & said a few words to the teachers - Left Butler at 10.15-and reached Rochester at 6.30 P.M.
- took supper dressed & at a few minutes after 8. was at the home of Mrs Hess-[?] with Anne to P.E. Club Sociable - & heard Mrs Taylor, Mrs Maurer, Mr & Mrs D. M. Anthony Miss Shoty, Mrs Sanford met Hamilton & [?] give talks on their foreign travels last summer.
Found a letter from Mrs. Harper saying she would visit [?] Christmas & New Years
This A.M. Papers report that my resolution was passed at Detroit by the [?] Federation of [?] Pres. Sam'l Gompers there-
Pres. there-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to teachers at the Court House in Butler County, Pennsylvania before leaving for Rochester. She attended a P.E. Club Sociable and received a letter from Mrs. Harper. Her resolution was passed at Detroit by the Federation of Pres. Sam'l Gompers.

entries.fullText: Sent Miss Shaw $20-just one half her fee-she will have to pay out ot it $8. for [?] & to pay out of my half $18.45 for 4 hours.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent Miss Shaw $20, half of her fee, and explained how much Miss Shaw would have to pay out of it.

entries.fullText: Miss Hawley absent from a cold-I went down town, paid up [?] for Bonnet-Basch for now fold spectacles - to [?] there & [?] last Autumn- [?] [?] to Dr. Landord = he put iodine on gum of left eye tooth - upper - which has badly swollen & very blood red for two weeks - not much sore- & not at all harmful - and ugly looking-Mrs Lannett telephones for sister Mary & self to take Christmas dinner with [?] we accepted-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to town to pay for new spectacles and a dental appointment. She also received an invitation to Christmas dinner from Mrs. Lannett and accepted with her sister Mary.

entries.fullText: Mrs Harper arrived at 5.30 this P.M. from her Winifreds - Rutland Vt.
entries.summaryText: Mrs Harper arrived from Rutland Vt.

entries.fullText: Mrs Harper spent forenoon at her Oculists Bissell & at Dentist J.E. Sunford & at stores
entries.summaryText: Mrs Harper went to the oculist and dentist and stores.

entries.fullText: Working on interview for McClures syndicate - on Queen Victoria. Mrs Harper's expenses from N.Y.City & return paid of them to come & do this
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is working on an interview for McClures syndicate about Queen Victoria. Mrs Harper's expenses from N.Y.City & return paid of them to come & do this.

entries.fullText: didn't go to church both Mrs Harper & self worked on the trails of extracts from favorable senate or house reports for a 16th amendment
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs Harper worked on the trails of extracts from favorable senate or house reports for a 16th amendment. They didn't go to church.

entries.fullText:
Please tell me the number of election districts
in New York State: in Greater New York, by boroughs.
Also the average cost per district of holding the
several elections; cost including printing of ballots,
clerk hire, rent, &c. 3. Is the community divided
into election districts in proportion to number of
voters and, if so, what is the maximum and minimum
number of voters per district? 4. From what
fund are the expenses of election paid? 5. By whom
primarily are the various details arranged?
J.D.R.

1. In the State there are 4,768 election districts;
in New York city there are 1,522, divided as follows:
In Manhattan, 811; in the Bronx, 72; in Kings, 516;
in Queens, 76; in Richmond, 47. 2. We do not
know. 3. Yes; the districts are to contain as nearly
as possible 400 voters and not more than 600. 4. By
the county or city. 5. The Secretary of State and
the County Clerk officially; the political details by
the county committee of each party.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony answers a series of questions about election districts in New York State, including the number of districts, the cost per district, the number of voters per district, and who arranges the details.
